												You awake, prisoner?Because Irreverend Opinions is about to enter the province of Morrowind.---The BlurbA staggering quest of epic proportions, you begin as a vision-touched prisoner aboard a boat, sent from the capital of imperial Tamriel to the remote, swamp-and-desert island of Morrowind. An incredible journey of discovery, betrayal, deicide, vengeance, and conquest spreads out from there.Open world game with heavy RPG elements and storyline.The GoodVery well-polished game with the old "Daggerfall" Kirkbride lore touch, which is to say "you can drown in the world's content".  The plot is sublime, with hours of invested time needed to complete it, with epic proportions matched only by juggernauts of the gaming industry.  The engine allows for an incredible amount of flexibility and freedom - you can spend time to become any kind of character you would desire, and there are multiple paths to get to the final plot.Detail is given to pretty much everything in the game, and if you are a curious explorer, you can get lost in the environment.  Despite the outdated graphics by today's standards, the sheer level of content is overwhelming, and sets a standard that is sadly unmet since.  The musical score matches the scale of the setting, and fans of the game will instantly recognise the strains of Morrowind's soundtrack - along with the pang of longing that it will bring.Bethesda kept to it's normal tradition of making the game extremely moddable, and even supported the game well past the three expansions they released for it; more quests and equipment has been released officially[www.elderscrolls.com] simply to enhance the game that little bit more, and if you wish to mod it further with extra content, the Nexus[www.nexusmods.com] holds a lot of quality content.The BadThe UI is often confusing and convoluted*, with bizarre choices for default keys (E to jump, space to interact) and there is often a lack of explanation for terms and controls.  The melee interface is not intuitive, and for modern gamers will feel lacking for the effort you need to take.Modern players will be more than slightly turned off by the very aged graphics*, and the sound effects are somewhat lacking*.  The plot does not often leave much explanation for steps needing to be taken, which can leave confusion and frustration in it's wake.  Almost everything in the wilderness wants to kill you.As usual, Bethesda's game engine is less than stable; an official set of patches are available here[www.paulcarr.com.au], and here[www.nexusmods.com], to counter this.* Suggestions to alleviate this are listed below.The UglyCliff racers.  The begging elf in Tribunal.SuggestionsPlayers will likely want to download and install the unofficial patches[www.paulcarr.com.au], and the code patch[www.nexusmods.com], to stabilize the engine; then the Morrowind Sound & Graphics Overhaul[www.ornitocopter.net] to improve the quality of the UI, default sounds, and graphics somewhat.  Following that, the official content patches[www.elderscrolls.com] add extra content, and the Tamriel Rebuilt[www.nexusmods.com] project will add even more to the sandbox you have to roam in.After all of that, if you care to do some more modding, the game world is, proverbially, your oyster.The Summary9/10 for this one, simply because the sheer amount of content and effort they put in overcomes a good portion of the poor graphics, the bugs, and poor UI choices they made.---If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
ber 15, 2016
												I first played Morrowind back in 2011 after having heard about The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim. I was looking for TES games for the PS2 before I happened upon Morrowind and found to my excitement, it was on the Classic Xbox which I still have, and when I started playing it; I fell in love with it, the old 2002 graphics, the music, everything.Fast forward to 2016, my Xbox Classic is dying, Morrowind lags, the journal is massive and with my computer upgraded, I figured it was time to take a chance and see if Morrowind could run on my PC and it did, unsurprisingly, I bought it just two days before this review was posted and the game is still as fantastic as it was my first time.Just about every recommended review speaks for this game, I can hardly do Morrowind anymore justice with this review. It's beautiful. It is a masterpiece, a true example of what an RPG is all about. It holds up incredibly well, it deffinatly outshines Skyrim in some areas.The following pro's and con's concern newer players, but do contain a hint of my own personal feelings.Pros:Music - is crisp and beautiful, still has that same feeling of wonder and beauty as it did during my first playthrough, and definitely one of the games highlights.The gameplay - while dated with hit-or-miss combat (at low levels this is litteral), holds up very nicely, it's no Oblivion, and it's definitely no Skyrim.Unique Fauna - You get wild life in this game you can only get in ESO, unless you go to Solstheim with all the wolves, Bears, Spriggans and Draugr.Enchanting - is fantastic, you can set the power and radius of an enchantment, particularly on weapons (this is especially true when applied offensivly).Spells - are the same as Enchanting, who doesn't want to make a spell that can lower their immune system?Cons:Difficult to Mod - the Steam version of the game requires the dates on certain files to be changed in addition to a few other things before the game can be modded. More info on this can be found in some discussion threads, or online.Lack of official Plug-in/Add-on Content - Examples include Bitter Coast Sounds and The Siege at Fort Firemoth. I don't understand why Bethesda excluded it from the GOTY release at all, there are alternatives to obtaining these plug-ins, however, I've personally run into trouble getting them to work.Crash Closing - Game sometimes crashes when exiting, it's perfectly fine however, it does no damage to your saves. From what I understand, it was an issue with the original release, I believe the unofficial Morrowind coding patch fixes this. Combat - While not a problem for me, I can see it would be irking for players who came off of Skyrim. Hitting an opponant relies on the amount of fatigue you have and the amount of time you've put into the skill related to your weapon of choice. This can be particularly unfortunate if you are in a fist fight with an angry, loin cloth-clad Nord, low on fatigue, and terrible with your weapon of choice.Cliff-Racers - I would never change these guys for the world, they are perfect the way they are, though, they get annoying, fast! Especially if you are out in the Molag-Amur region and you've managed to attract seven of them without realising it, and as an added bonus you're level one with a dagger. These guys can be silent, and if not careful, deadly in a flock. Cliff-Racers are also subject to memes, look up a few, you'll see what I mean.On a side note, Cliff-Racers are a pro for me, but to newer players they may be more of a con than anything else.That's about all I can say really.The Game is fantastic, it is a product of its time, and perfect for it; and until Bethesda releases Arena and Daggerfall to Steam, it's a good place to start if you want to experience TES as we know it today, and it's a wonderful game to pick up if you're looking to escape the snowy climate of Skyrim, or the hilly terrain of Cyrodill. I deffinatly reccomend this game with gusto.

content:
r 27, 2015
												I have been playing The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind Game of the Year Edition for years now albeit a bit on and off. I predominantly spent my time playing it on the Xbox.Some say that it is a bit dated on the graphics front but you have to remember that this game is 12 years old. Despite this, however, I think as far as the graphics and the general game play goes it was way ahead of it's time.With Morrowind you really don't start with much and you really don't get a lot of help. The sheer fact that you have to work hard to get other characters in the game to like you enough to actually tell you anything worthwhile is gripping. You can join a whole host of different factions and this helps to build your character. As some factions do not like each other you can end up being slightly more disliked by one faction or race than another. Ultimately the games main story line never changes but the multitude of side quests is mind boggling and if you can't even be bothered with those you can spend an age just running around collecting valuable and rare items and increasing your stats to almost godly levelsThe animals: If you think that Dragons are bad my goodness you haven't met a Cliff Racer (Be mega wary of the diseased or blighted ones especially if you are a weaker character)Favourite 'Easter Egg': It has to be the Mudcrab Merchant. If you find this little guy make sure you have a Mark and Recall spell so you can find him again as he is situated on a tiny island in the middle of no-where. He is the richest merchant in the entire game Little tip: Listen to the music. The music is set to warn you of any impending danger. If you are being attacked it will change quickly, if you are going to be it will be more subtle (But don't be fooled sometimes the game likes to play the first few notes of the attack sequence music before launching into the normal calm outdoors music) I did write a slightly longer review originally but couldn't fit it all in. If you want that then let me know

content:
ber 13, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls series: Oblivion and Online are ok, Skyrim is pretty good, but THIS game is my RPG codifier. Slower, quieter, more subtle than it's succesors, you will find no demons falling out of the sky or dragons setting towns aflame in Morrowind. Instead, the land is threatened by a slowly encroaching volcanic wasteland, a disease spreading amongst the populace, and plots, upheaval, and assasinations amongst the ruling and religious bodies. There will be no setpiece battles in Morrowind; your enemies lurk in the darkest corners of the world and are content to wait for you there and work their plots from afar. It is a genuinely different and fascinating story.

content:
y 4, 2015
												Ahh Morrowind is so close to home. You play as The Nerevarine as prophesied to defeat the Dagoth Ur, who have tapped into the power of an artefact known as the Heart of Lorkhan in a bid to exert control over the inhabitants of Morrowind. This game is set predominantly on the island of Vvardenfell, just off the coast of Stonefall, in northern Morrowind.Any hardcore Elder Scrolls fan would instantly feel at home with the rich characterisation, role-playing elements, visual details, soundtrack and the quintessential open-world environment. It is still the best of all the Elder Scrolls games, because of the magnitude of the game for its time and the back-to-basics approach in role-playing - tremendous storyline, realistic characterisation, interaction and progression.There are weaknesses to this game however, the UI is not particularly helpful to meta-gamers (c.f. Oblivion min-maxing), the journal system whilst improved in the expansion, is still rather cumbersome to navigate, the inherent 'block' in combat can be difficult to get used to for some, as is the one-mouse-button attack and finally the graphics - this is a 2002 game, but thankfully the modding community has made graphic enhancement addons that could be easily installed and used with the game.Overall, this game is a gem.

content:
r 23, 2016
												Well here I am one year later. 185 hours and counting. I well only recently got back into Morrowind, I was being lazy and said to myself "heyyyy dude you love this game right? Why not play it vanilla?" and let me tell you my play through lasted an hour. I think the main reason no one can play vanilla Morrowind anymore is because the combat is frustrating and the graphics aren't what they used to be, oh and well you'll be very alone, no quest marker to hold your hand the entire way, how sad. Okay this game really isn't for everyone, I would say it's very much an acquired taste, like this doesn't hold your hand at all in fact if it had quest arrows it would lead you down the wrong road on purpose. Because Morrowind hates you and everyone in it hates you, but to me that the beauty of it,you are forced to work your way up slowly, you are forced to get people to like you and you are forced to figure everything out yourself and that is one of the things i like about Morrowind; It doesn't hold your hand and it trusts you to be intelligent enough to play it. Trust me this isn't for everyone it takes allot of getting used to. I really recommend some mods like accurate attack,a good graphics mod or texture pack and the code patch, because they will help your enjoyment of this game. Because there really is allot to enjoy such as: The world is huge, not in square miles but in the amount of things there are to do and find, there are so many cities,villages,dungeons and just intersting out of the ordinary stuff. The magic system like you can collect spell effects and make your own spells, you can do so much with it, and in what other game do you get to fly and turn invisible? I also really really just like the island of Vvardenfell like its so rich and detailed there is so much to it, its just so alien and unique that you just want to explore it, But you can't! Because when you start you are the weakest thing on the entire island and this world will put you in your place, and i really like that, you're just normal you're not the dragon born, you're just a normal entity on an island that really hates you and you really need to grind and exploit to become powerful, you really need to work for your power it isn't just handed to you.speaking of not being special, the story is amazing (to me at least) it's not quite "you are a all powerful hero and the only one who can save the world! go beat up the pending doom and save the day!" you're not special most of the later game is all about cheating the system being something you're clearly not. I'm not going to go too much into it because the story should be enjoyed not spoiled.I would recommend this to someone who can enjoy an old game, and who doesn't need it to hold their hand. Morrowind is a masterpiece even if it is subjectively so. It has many flaws yet many fixes and ways to work around these flaws. But it is also one of the most in depth and rich games i have ever played and there isn't quite anything like it out there. My opinion is best taken with a pinch of salt as is Morrowind taken with a bucket of patience.

29, 2016
												First I would say this game has quite a learning curve. I would consider 30 hours a "college try". So If you're trying to get into the game it has some commitment to it.Pick your race, which has benefits/weaknesses, pick your major and minor skills, which decide how fast/slow you level and progress. Melee combat may seem dated but is a very complex system based on dice rolls factoring everything from your fatigue when you swing to the condition of your weapon before it calculates damage. Magic system is leagues above future titles(looking at you Skyrim) with thousands of spells that you can create. Tons of gear choices with 3 classes of armor and unarmored as well. Lots of skills, some of which are more rewarding than others. The game is less balanced than future titles but thats part of the charm.Quests and travel really set this game apart from most games. No hand holding here. You really have to read and comprehend your goals before you can set off acomplishing tasks. There is usually several ways to organically complete quest, for instance one of the first quest in the Thieves guild has you stealing a diamon from a local shopkeeper but you can just purchase it and lie to the guild when you turn in the quest.Graphics are the most dated part of this game, but there is good news. Its an Elder Scrolls title which of coarse means MODs! One in paticular called Morrowind Sound and Graphics Overhaul or MGSO for short is a complete package of graphical updates with loads of bug fixes added as well. The Installer for MGSO is fairly simple and I've recommended it to several people (including a 51 year old computer illiterate co worker) and they havent had any trouble installing it.I love Morrowind and recommend it fullheartedly. 9.9/10

content:
, 2015
												If you want to see the mods I'm using and the general experience (in my own unique way...) I do an occasional series on YouTube. Enjoy.


YouTube™ Video: Let's Play The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind (Badly) - #1: Answering Lots of Questions 

			Views: 4,705		

			If you like it, like it! Leave a comment! Tell your friends! Tell Twitter! Tell strangers! Tell everybody! But be wary of the strangers. Especially if they're offering you sweets.		

This game is still as amazing as it ever was. From the opening beats of the theme music, the atmosphere will wrap around you like a blanket and never let go.This is the only game I have ever found myself just wandering around feeling like I'm 'there'. Its immersion comes from intricately-written storylines, a world full of enormous detail, and a complete lack of hand-holding. Unlike Oblivion, there are no quest markers to follow. If you get lost, you get lost. And wow, will you enjoy getting lost. Everywhere you turn there is something new to see - sweeping landscapes, towering mountains, bubbling lava pools and farming country all await. Even just exploring the little islands that dot the map is an exciting pastime, almost a quest in itself.If you prefer completing quests and bashing things there is plenty of that as well. Tribunal and Bloodmoon, the expansions in the GOTY edition, have a LOT of bashing things. Be warned: the bashing things mechanic is actually done on dice rolls, and not direct fighting mechanics. This means that to begin with you may not be bashing things as successfully as you might like.The magic system is great. Shooting fireballs into the deep night sky from the top of a hill is one of my favourite things...but then so is zapping necromancers with massive explosions, so there is something for everyone.The graphics were impressive for 2002 and I remember being blown away back then, particuarly by the water effects ('Yay, I've got the right shader model!'). However, if you choose it, the modding community has transformed the visuals into a spectacular world which is faithful to the original whilst taking advantage of modern-day technology.If you really want to live in the world - which you will - you can also add fishing, food and crafting mods and never touch an official quest.I go back to this game again...and again...and again. It kept me up until the early hours of the morning when it first came out. It's my go-to game when my internet access fails. The Prima guide was bedtime reading for weeks (don't do this until you have thoroughly explored for yourself, however - 'thoroughly' meaning 'for years').And then there's the musical score... Don't be in any doubt about whether to buy this. I'm not even much of a fantasy games-type person, but this is less of a fantasy game and more of a living, breathing, utterly believable world in which your role is as important or as minor as you want it to be.Whether camping around the coast, catching fish for dinner and sitting by the fire, or engaging in huge battles with a big sword, worrying about your levelling and never bothering to sleep, you will eventually love Morrowind more than anything else in your collection. If Bethesda ever manages to capture this feeling in a game again I will be the happiest woman alive...

content:
er 5, 2015
												Morrowind is a pinnacle in the Elder Scrolls series, it was a massive advancement on Daggerfall, with it's incorporation of proper 3D, and benefited from the development of the smaller gaming region by focusing on the island of Vvardenfell. In typical Elder Scrolls style the primary narrative is fairly formulaic revolving around the prophecy of the Nerevarine, but where it deviates is the impact that this has not only on the religious aspects of the world, a part of prophecy that is not often explored in fantasy narratives but also on the wider political spectrum of Tamriel, what if Akulakhan had truly awoken?Morrowind more than its sequels allowed players to truly delve into the depths and world building of the Elder Scrolls universe, yet still offered a decent leveling system, combined with it's simplistic conflict mechanics. On this level, as a game to be interacted with Morrowind required much improvement, partially done by modders that covered over and developed the game in directions the smaller group of original developers would never have managed.Morrowind is still an excellent game if you want to truly explore a fantasy environment that is utterly unique, and become immersed and explore an alien world, with skills and abilities that far surpass those offered to players in earlier and later Elder Scrolls games. Although not as technically accomplished as its sequels, Morrowind more than excels them in its vibrant and diverse world.

content:
, 2014
												Unlike the newer two iterations of the Elder Scrolls, Morrowind is a role-playing game, not an action adventure. Player choice and character skill is what matters. In Skyrim and Oblivion, progress in the game is controlled by point-and-click combat and mini games where player skill is what matters. In Morrowind, the skill of a character is what matters, with hidden dice rolls and comparisons controlling successes and failures.Some will complain that the combat is clunky, and that they hate missing a rat 20 times and dying as a result. But if you have a skill of 5 in short blade, why are you using a dagger? Building or picking a class, allocating attribute points correctly, and choosing a logical strategy for your character is what makes this game so much different from Skyrim, where anyone can cast spells, swing swords, and sneak with extreme proficiency.By making you start off small, learn and mold your character's strengths and weaknesses, and lick the boots of every NPC around you, Morrowind lets you grow from a worthless, scummy, ex-con n'wah to the all powerful, well respected Nerevar Incarnate.

 "Each event is preceded by Prophecy, but without the hero, there is no Event" - Zurin ArctusThe Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind was a bold and brave step for Bethesda, finally coming out of the world of 2D and into the 3D. The immersion value increases when you install the Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul (MGSO), but the vanilla experience is the way to go.I always come back to play Morrowind at least once a year, and find myself stuck in the land of Vvardenfell again and again, and I would recommend any fan of the Elder Scrolls to enjoy this experience.

content:
8, 2016
												One of, if not the best TES game there is (my personal favorite is still Daggerfall)Pros:-Good story-Quests are usually interesting and have great dialogue (and there are quite a lot of humorous ones)-Tons of lootable items-You can use candles inplace of torches, even lanterns and some other light sources-Combat can be confusing, but rewarding when you work towards improving your character-Very atmospheric, even for a dated engine with dated graphics -Cool large world to explore, one of the more unique locations of the TES series-Complex mechanics (this could also fall under cons for younger audiences, but it's a pro to vets)-Interesting characters (that walk like they have to take a ♥♥♥♥ :-P)-Very open ended world, you can flat out fail the main storyline by killing important NPCs-Very rewarding character progression. Go from a physically disabled manbaby, to a God far greater than mr. Dragonborn-Pretty modular armor system. Less so than Daggerfall, moreso than Oblivion and Skyrim-Cliff Racers-Tons of skills to help evolve your character-more stuff that I should probably add hereCons:-Cliff Racers-Out dated engine-Hard to look at graphics and models (although the world is still somehow beautiful)-Combat is very RNG heavy (Progressing weapon skills lowers this)-Sometimes confusing quest locations (I personally very rarely get lost, but sometimes a quest cave isn't exactly where you're told)-Hard to get into for younger audiences (The learning curve plus the ancient combat may turn most people away)All in all a solid 9/10 RPG.A tip I'll give to newcomers; your starting weapon skill MATTERS. Going with Long sword skill but not Short sword, matters. You most likely will get the ♥♥♥♥ beaten out of you by those pillow noming rats if you go in with a weapon you didn't set for you to be skilled in. If you end up wanting to level different weapon skills, practice on lower level enemies slightly later on, it'll make it less of a headache. Or shell out ♥♥♥♥♥ons of gold to the dedicated trainers (gold is pretty easy to get imo, an armor set from a specific someone that tries to tickle you from your sleep is a good way to make early money. Unless you want to use it, of course.)I urge anyone interested to try this game. Try to get through the first few hours, you'll thank yourself. It's brutal early on, but once your skills come along, the game is very enjoyable. Most of the negative reviews are from people that don't have the patience for the early game. Trust me, as someone who falls under the younger generation, it IS worth it.

content:
, 2016
												I might be a bit blinded by nostilgia when saying this, but honestly, this is my favorite of all 5 of the elder scroll's games, heres why.The characters in the game all feel slightly diffrent and for a game of its time it still holds up well, the graphics arnt nearly as bad as they seem and honestly hold no regaurd in the game quality because it was made 10 years before skyrim.The combat can be a chanlenge as it is all chance based on weather or not your attack will land, this is, of course, based on the level of a skill, which caps out at 100. You will run slow as hell at the start, but rather then in skyrim where you can beat the whole game in one sitting if your fast enough and know enough about the game and where to find things this game FORCES you to grind out levels and get really good gear, build a reputation, make allies, and basicly unite a whole province in order to battle a huge threat to tamriel.Before the end of the main story your treated as a outlander, A random person who just appeared on the shoars of morrowind and should be treated as nothing more. But by the end, your treated as a god, the saviour of all the land, hero of the people, and slayer of demond's, and thus people like you more, adding yet another layer of complexity that skyrim wont offer you.Over all this is game you just have to sit down, put some headphone's in, close the blinds and experince for yourself, no words can discribe first setting out into the land of morrowind.Other then "wow, this looks beutiful" and "WHERE THE ♥♥♥♥ AM I GOING!"

content:
er 16, 2013
												Morrowind is something special, something different. Imagine three times the quests and content of Skyrim compressed into one small island, with so much lore and depth that you can lose yourself for hours and hours. Sure, it isn't a really pretty game, but slap MGSO on it and you've got an astonishingly good looking game to complement it's other aspects. You see, in Skyrim you find out you are dragonborn... cool! Yes, that means you get to incinerate people, make them fly off of cliffs etc. In Morrowind though, you start off as almost weaker than mudcrabs, but become a GOD by the end of the game, quite literally. Feel like flying around the whole map without even needing console commands? Go ahead. Want to jump like a super hero from Seyda Neen to Balmora? Do it! Kill the end game boss in one hit? Yes, you can do that. The possibilities are endless, and even though all of the above is true, that doesn't mean you're the strongest thing around, there are still monsters that are quite dangerous even in the late game, see what's different between newer entries and Morrowind? Yes, FREEDOM, to become whatever you like. Now, Morrowind isn't perfect, but it's probably the best game in the series. These days, even though it has aged well enough, it can be very difficult to get into, and since you are thrown instantly into a massive world with only a small dagger, quite confusing. But don't give up. Keep playing, and you could turn your 3 hours of frustration into your 300 hour playthrough of the best game experience you've ever had.So I don't think I need to tell you how much I recommend this game. But as I said, it's not without flaws, it's simply that the strong points make it so amazing that you won't need to worry about the flaws. I think there is something in this game for everyone, and it's an experience that can't be missed. Grab it in the christmas sale (it's almost always on sale then), grab MGSO, also known as Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul, and make sure your body is ready for one of the best PC games ever made. Have fun!

content:
, 2014
												Morrowind in my opinion is the best installment in the Elder Scrolls series so far. The amount of content and freedom the game offers you is insane. It's the type of game that doesn't tend to hold your hand, but give it a chance and the game will open itself up to you and you'll soon find yourself sucked in to it's world.The graphics and battle system may be a little too outdated for some, but because of the games awesome modding community, there's a variety of mods you can choose from to improve your experience (i recommend Morrowind Overhaul).The best thing about this game is that YOU choose how you want to play. Boasting a huge open world, hundreds of quests, a variety of races and classes to choose from, you'll never run out of things to do.I invite you to give this game a try, for the amount of content you get in game, it's definitely worth the asking price.

content:
er 25, 2014
												Original review:"No time to explain, n'wah, buy the game! ♥♥♥♥, that cliff rider is coming, bai!"Maybe back in the days when I wrote that review, it was just an inside joke, a horror and nightmare that people who have played or heard of Morrowind would only get. Looking at it now, maybe it's a bit unfair to leave it as it is, especially considering how I feel about Morrowind and how much time I've spent on it, long before I got it on Steam.ForewordMorrowind....It'd be hard to capture everything about the game, and it'd be twice as hard to put it into words, but I can at least try, not just for my own satisfaction but for every possible person that might come across this review and actually stop to read it.Morrowind.The third game in The Elder Scrolls series, released back in the distant 2002. A lot of words could be used to describe it, for me personally it'd be just one - fascinating. For me personally, Morrowind is the kind of game that years later, playing Skyrim, I realized how much it has affected me - I'd always compare Skyrim and its mechanics and story to Morrowind; many people may not find it fair, but it's deep within me, and I'm sure that many people who feel about Morrowind the same way have done it, more than once. I also admit I teared up twice - once when I realized that the Morrowind main theme is incorporated within the Skyrim OST and once when I got to visit Solstheim... The latter one, especially, woke up a deep feeling of nostalgia, turning the camera around and looking at the Red Mountain, wishing I could just jump on that boat and set foot there once again.. set foot back home.You see, Morrowind is a masterpiece, not only one of its time, but a masterpiece that will stick along for years... It's no lie that it's old now. It is, indeed, and its graphics might not be as welcoming as they used to be back then, but the world and story it has to offer, it's something I'm yet to find in another game.But enough fuzzy warm feeling of nostalgia, let me tell you why I believe this would probably remain one of the games that I'll always come back to...What is MorrowindMorrowind is a timeless RPG, one that will take years for others to catch up on. While some may disagree, I believe everything from the details of the atmosphere of the game, through the sandbox mechanics that allow you and encourage you to do everything you think of, all the way to the combat system that I've seen people complaining about, all this is polished nearly to perfection.Morrowind is unforgiving, it won't hold your hand, it won't tell you what to do, it won't make things easy for you. It's a combination of detailed conversations, exploration and thought that is required to reach your goals. One wrong turn along the way and you'll find yourself in a cave full of Daedras, and if you manage to overcome the odds, your reward will be there waiting for you.Morrowind will make your imagination go nuts. You want to be a deadly wizard, using spells no one has ever heard of, well then, be one! You want to be the most powerful being walking this earth, Gods' demise, unmatched by no power, divine or mortal? Be one! You are allowed to do nearly everything in it, you just need to find your way to do it.Morrowind is frustration, trust me, not once or twice you'll walk into enemies severely overpowered than you are and they will kill you, over and over and over again. Cliff racers will haunt your dreams and mudcrabs will give you the most challenging fights you've ever experienced... Maybe except for that ebony beggar dude, ♥♥♥♥ that guy seriously.Morrowind is the land where you are no one. Brace yourself for being treated and called any kinds of names, from the popular 'outlander' to the so annoying 'scum'. Question is, would that break you or would you reclaim the destiny of the Nerevarine, Protector of Morrowind?Morrowind is .... perfect, in its imperfection.Closing wordsI doubt I'd ever be even close to properly reviewing this game. I doubt I'd ever be close to being one of those fellas that know every tiny bit of detail around its story and lore, I doubt that I'd ever be able to even explore its world and gameplay fully just because of how huge it is.... but I'm sure of one thing - that I'll always shiver and tear up a bit every time I hear:"Wake up... Stand up.. There you go. You were dreaming, what's your name?"

content:
er 3, 2014
													When I got this game, I thought it was terrible. I thought that my game was bugged because I was getting point blank misses. Now, however, this is my favorite game of all time. Though it was a hard start, I can tell you why this game is so amazing.	You start the game extremely underpowered, with a set of terrible clothes, a dagger, 87 gold and, if you are smart. some extra trinkets to sell and a terrible lockpick.	I would also like to note that this is a hardcore RPG with a few action concepts, such as real time combat. However, much of the game is based on your character's skill, not your skill. So, if you have a bad short blade skill, you will get at least 9 out of 10 hits as a miss. In fact, I would even argue that this game and skyrim (I have played both) can be classified into different subgenres because of the differences.	Later in the game, it is the opposite of the beginning. You become an unbeatable god. It is the greatest feeling I have ever had in a game. This is why I reccomend this game.	One more thing to add. If you are considering buying goat simulator, this game can simulate the feeling of goat simulator with console commands. Add these commands and start punching people:player-> setacrobatics 300player-> setathletics 2000player-> sethandtohand 3000player-> sethealth 9999999999player-> setstrengh 999999

7, 2011
												After beating Skyrim and putting lots of hours into it I loved it. So I thought I would try to beat the older games and I just beat Morrowind recently, all I can say is that I loved it! THE GOOD STUFF:The world is looks beautiful (even better with mods), theres alot of cool weapons and armour types, lots of scary enemies and cool ones and the main antagonist is awsome. You can even go to Solstheim and do lots of cool stuff there that is also there in the Skyrim version of Solstheim. There is alot more good things but its hard to say them without spoiling it so go check for yourself.THE BAD STUFF:Only few bad things was I didn't like was combat, its like rolling a dice or something to hit the enemy so if you have bad stats you will miss alot, BUT if you take time to level your stats up or go to trainers for your skills you will rarely miss, unless someone casts spells to lower your stats or you fight an enemy with high luck/agility. Ranged combat sucks even more if its not leveled up high enough, you will waste so much arrows but it does make some fights easier. Another kinda bad thing is the game is really slow compaired to the other games but you can make potions and spells or find enchanted items to make you move faster.I reccomend this game if you love difficult RPGs and Elder Scrolls, with a few mods you can fix up all the problems and have lots of fun!

content:
1, 2014
												The Elder Scrolls lll: Morrowind is acknowledged by many TES fans as the best game in the series. It has a few features which other Elder Scrolls games failed to accomplish. The ability to kill every single npc in the game you want, regardless if it's part of a quest or not; The lack of quest markers and instead having to rely on directions and your common sense; The privilege of taking any house you want and call it your own. Not only that: the world feels completely different. It's not your average fantasy game filled with unicorns and dragons, instead the game throws more unique creatures at you: Kwama's, Nix-Hound's, Netches, Ogrim's, Kagouti just to name a few. Combat Some people hate it. Others love it. It depends on how you look at it. While in combat hitting someone does not necessarily mean it actually hits. Lots of factors play a role in this, such as the amount of stamina you have, how skilled you are in the weapon category (daggers, spears, longswords etc) and your agility attribute. If these parameters are high enough the game makes it count as a hit. The more you use a weapon in a certain category the more skilled you will become and thus essentially making you hit your target more often. This however also means you cannot easily switch from weapon to weapon. If your skill in daggers is 90 and you found an axe which does approximately 10 more damage than your current weapon it might be a better idea to stick with your dagger and move on as your low skill in axes might put you at a disadvantage. Exploration Exploring is extremely rewarding. There's always something cool and new to discover such as finding a wood elf plummeting to his death who carries the infamous scrolls of icarian flight which allows you to jump tremendous distances. Or who could have known the legendary dragon bone cuirass is locked away in a closet on a random island in the middle of nowhere? You will never know what treasures and garbage a cave has hidden. Quests As mentioned above there are no quest markers present in Morrowind. Instead you will need to rely on your brain and directions given by npc's. Quest items can also be freely sold to any merchant even though this may mean permanently breaking the entire quest once the merchant has stocked up on different wares.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 6, 2014
												I think a video game succeeds when it can immserse its players into its world.Morrowind does that, and it does it great.I've found myself lost within Morrowind's world several times, exploring every nook and cranny of Vvardenfell, talking to every NPC I can, learning more about Vvardenfell and its lore, and of course, killing monsters!The story in this game for me is much better than the story in Oblivion or Skyrim, to sum it up you're POSSIBLY the reincarnate of the badass Lord Nerevar and you are on a quest to save Morrowind from the ash blight storms. (and Dagoth Ur, remember that place from Arena?)It's amazing how you start as such a lowly and disgusting outlander, then you start to hone your abilities and stay true to who you're loyal to, and then you have the power to do anything you want! Then you're an invincible demi-god with 1000 acrobatics EASILY jumping across and around the whole map. The game for me is about the freedom to do anything, anywhere. The only limitations are the hardware and the engine, so go frickin' nuts.Though the game DOES have its flaws.-  RNG based combat (dice rolls) Excusable though, seeing how this is an RPG. Just seems odd to have RNG based combat in a game like this though.-  Uninteresting NPCs and boring towns-  Bugs.. Every (especially Bethesda) game has these though.Regarding the combat, I don't think combat has ever been good in an Elder Scroll game, especially the swing your mouse at the enemy type of combat in Arena in Daggerfall. The combat is this game fortunately doesn't depend on swinging your mouse like a madman (and RNG!).. but instead is dependent on dice rolls(same thing). The game takes every possible factor from how much fatigue you have to how far your enemy to your agility to your weapon skills is to determine whether you'll hit or miss. Your skill with a weapon also determines your chance to hit with that type of weapon, for example, you're more likely to hit enemies with Spear 100 then Spear 25 while using a spear.Despite its minor and/or major flaws, these can be fixed, and Morrowind still remains as a masterpiece that can never be replicated, which is why people are STILL playing the game in 2014, and why I'll still be playing in 2015.

content:
2016
												The best Elder Scrolls title, hands down. At the start of the game, you are thrown into an alien world, one that you would never expect to see youself in. Everything is different, to the odd fungus flora, to the floating jellyfish that are the Netch. You start as a lowly Outlander, and are constantly told that you, are a worthless outlander. And you don't belong. But as you progress, that will change. You will become an Outlander who barely can swing a sword, to the Nerevarine, legendary Dunmer Saint who can kill gods, and capture their souls. The satisfaction of this makes the game very rewarding and fun to play. Not to mention the amazing spell-creation system, that allows you to create any spell imaginable.  Now other than that, let's talk Story. Morrowind tells one of the greatest stories you will ever partake in. The 6th House has risen, and a blight pollutes Vvardenfell. Will you be the one to save Vvardenfell from this blight, and destroy the evil Dagoth Ur, who dwells in Red Mountain? Or who knows, you might just become arch-mage of Great House Telvanni. All of this is up to you. I definitely recommend Morrowind to anyone who enjoys a good story, a great RPG/openworld game, and a piece of art. But don't let graphics put you off! Morrowind is an amazing, must-play game! Alas, some people may be scaared of these "bad" graphics. That's why there's Morrowind Graphics and Sound Overhaul! It makes the game look like any modern game, so haha, there's no excuses now!

content:
9, 2016
												I wanted to wait a bit before writing a review.  This game does take a while to get used to, after all.So far, this is one of the best games I have played.  I have played Skyrim for several hundred hours (maybe not too "impressive," but still enough to have an informed opinion of it), and Oblivion for around 50.  Morrowind blows both these out of the water.Maybe it is partially the jump (for me) from console to PC.  Maybe it is just my mindset at the moment. But Morrowind makes its sequels look ... lackluster.  You begin the game with a vague idea of what you're doing and no clue who you are.  And truthfully, I'm not much farther than that in the main story.  And I am completely okay with that.  This game immediately makes you want to explore all of it.  It starts you off in a little town and teases you with these big names that are not so far away.  And, yeah, you can take a silt strider to them.  But frequently a quest makes you leave the big cities. And it is then that Morrowind shows it's true colors.  I walked out of the first town, no idea where I was going, and came upon a man falling from the sky, screaming, with a few scrolls on him that begged to be tried out.  And then I, too, was falling out of the sky.  I later came across a woman who had fallen in love with a man who had stolen her jewels and begged me to find the thief for her.  I walked into a strange-looking edifice and found it filled with high level dremora who quickly taught me that I was not yet welcome there.Save frequently, get a few mods (like the Real Signposts mod.  It truly is a must for navigation. And a mod to make you run faster will keep the game from seeming so slow.), and buy this game.  If you are a fan of the Elder Scrolls, or even of RPG's in general, you will not regret it.

content:
ber 20, 2014
												Morrowind is an intresting game, and is considered by many as the best in the Elder Scroll series.The art direction is vivid with bright colors and soft tones, while still maintaing a sense of mystery. While traveling across the province of Morrowind, you will encounter a wide array of NPCs, both mundane and intriguing. The combat is the worst of the past three Elder Scrolls, but you have a sense of peril unlike the more recent installments in the series. Some people give the idea that Morrowind is the most "hardcore" Elder Scroll game, which will cause some to waffle on purchasing the game. In reality, Morrowind is really not that hard of a game, sure, when you first start off things WILL be difficult, but once you get the hang of things and level up, it becomes a pleasant experience. Overall, if you find open world games, western RPGs, and/or adventure games your thing, you should purchase Morrowind. It may not be the best for everybody, but it is entertaining to most.

content:
, 2015
												The first thing i want to say about this game is, that Morrowind is my favourite game of all time, and i have played it for a lots and lots of hours during several years. If you havent ever tried Morrowind, but for an example played Skyrim or Oblivion, you most likely cant enjoy this game. Morrowind still has more RPG elements than Oblivion or Skyrim has, and that makes Morrowind so much better than the newer installations in the series. Want to kill gods and use their souls to make extremely powerful weapons? Did you happen to kill an important character that is connected to the main questline, but still want to complete it? Possible in Morrowind, but not in skyrim or Oblivion. In Morrowind each time you start a new game, you are thrown into the world as a new person, not dragonborn or "the hero of Kvatch". Each time you have the opportunity to create a character of your own choise and not let the game make decicions for you, like in Skyrim or Oblivion. Morrowind is not only the best game I have ever played, but also contains the best DLC pack I have ever played; Tribunal. I recommend this for everyone, especially for those who havent played Skyrim or Oblivion.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 15, 2016
												I could go into a lot of detail, but I'll keep this brief. This easily one of the best games ever made. At the very least, it's one of the best RPGs ever made.  (THE best in my humble opinion.) It's depth and complexity is completely unlike any game made today. There is infintely more to every single aspect of the game than just what meets they eye. The quests, the main story, the characters, the magic, the stat system. -There is absolutely no hand holding-This game will never forgive you for being inexperienced-You can't just go around chopping everything in your path to bits like you can in Skyrim. There are creatures that will absolutely decimate you without mercy. -You'll get lost trying to find places (A lot) -You'll get confused and stuck on quests -You will struggle to create a character with decent stats-You will miss important items or details-Spend hours upon hours trudging through the wilderness at a snail's pace-I'm not joking. Speed is an ACTUAL SKILL you have to level up. -You will fail to hit a mudcrab standing right in front of you with your weapon-You will be forever finding new gameplay mechanics, locations, or items you never knew existed.-You will love the music-You will develop and ungodly hatred for cliffracers-YOU CAN KILL MAIN QUESTLINE CHARACTERS. Pay attention. If you kill certain characters you might not ever be able to complete some quests or guilds.The game is not without it's shortcomings, but (some of) it's flaws are part of the fun. Yes, the graphics are bad but it's 15 years old for crying out loud. That's what mods are for. The combat system can be frustrating at first when your skills are low. There is no magicka generation. Glicthes, bugs and exploits are not uncommon. THE BOTTOM LINE- This game is an absolute masterpiece. Buy it right now. Cherish it, bask in it's glory. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												The Elder Scrolls III Morrowind is one of the best purchases and games I have ever played in my life. I had first played Morrowind back in Middle School on the old Xbox system and fell in love with the world, the mystery, and the open endedness of the game world. After wanting the game really bad, I decided to purchase it on Steam and it was a wise decision. Morrowind gives the player the ability to truly do whatever they please, create the character of their dreams, and explore an enormous world with amazing characters, creatures, and cities to explore. The Elder Scrolls III Morrowind is certainly one of the best Elder Scrolls games I have played out of the entire series and I wish more of the game would have the same feel as Morrowind. I would certainly recommend Morrowind if you love a good RPG, but also if you love open ended exploreation and the ability to go anywhere and do anything you please. Out of 5 stars, I would give Morrowind a 5.Also included in this purchase is the official expansion packs for Morrowind as well. The first expansion pack The Elder Scrolls III: Tribunal takes the player to a new location called Mournhold the capital of Morrowind Proper. The expansion is exciting but after a few hours of exploring it does get boring as it is possible to discover everything you can in this expansion. The city does add more quests to the game which is exciting but the quests are certaintly not easy and may take a while, but that is what makes the expansion great. Of course if you purchase Morrowind on Steam you will automantically get this expansion, but out of 5 stars, I would give Tribunal a 3.The second expansion pack is The Elder Scrolls III: Bloodmoon, which adds a large island territory called Solstheim which the player can travel to and complete new quests to stop the Bloodmoon prophecy from taking place. The island adds even more beautiful scenery, creatures, and towns and cities to be discovered. It is certainly an entertaining expansion as the player is exposed to new landscapes different from those of Vvardenfell and it adds yet another good 15 hours to the already massive game. Of course if you purchase Morrowind on Steam you will automatically get this expansion, but out of 5 stars, I would give Bloodmoon a 5.

content:
8, 2014
												Morrowind. Started actually playing the game after periods of playing for a bit and then stopping for ages. I'm hooked now. Im only level 3, but I'm so enthralled by the game and how fun and addictive it is. I've played almost all the Bethesda games, Skyrim, Oblivion, Fallout 3 and Fallout New Vegas. I loved them all, so naturally, I thought I would try it out after hearing so many positive things about it. It's extremely hard and unrewarding at the beginning, because it does'nt hold your hand. Also, the combat is a dice roll mechanic, meaning the more skilled you are with a particular weapon, the more likely you are to hit your target. I know it sounds a bit odd, but it's a gem of a game. Stick with it, it's so worth it. Keep grinding and keep your eye on the prize, and you'll have no problem with the game. 10/10 definitely recommend.

content:
er 28, 2012
												Morrowind was my introduction to the Elder Scroll's series. I had heard many great things about it, mostly about how it emulated Gothic and the Might & Magic series which made it seem very interesting to me. And while I don't hold it in the same high esteem as many other fans it is still a game I did enjoy despite it's many flaws.Morrowind is an exploration driven RPG. What that means is essentially that the story, combat and skills take a backseat to a huge open world that you can explore at will with little or no boundaries imposed. Now what separates a good exploration RPG from a bad one is both the uniqueness of the locations you can explore and especially the challenge of those locations. One of the worst mistakes an exploration RPG can make is to use leveled enemies or any similar system. If the chance of you entering a new cave only to be running out 30 seconds later with a big scary monster in close pursuit is a non factor then it will quickly become boring and predictable. Likewise if every location is too similar to the last one you will lose that driven to find new caves and castles to loot.While the challenge you get from skipping too far ahead is not quite as good as you can find in other games and the locations do have a number of repeats Morrowind still does a good enough job that you will want to keep searching for new locations and secrets. A number of very cool travel abilities, in particular the one that allows you to jump halfway across the island in a single bound, makes for some very good exploration at times.In terms of combat however the game is very simple and not very entertaining, killing enemies feels more like a chore than anything else and although the spell making system and enchantment system is somewhat interesting it doesn't help enough that you won't find yourself dreading running into yet another enemy. The equipment and loot system is fairly detailed but not very well thought out, mostly notably the clothing/armor system is needlessly complicated without that complexity actually adding anything to the game.The storyline and dialog is not particularly impressive, not as much because of a lack of quality but because there isn't really enough of it to be judged and what little there is tends to be very generic and not very detailed. The quests should be mentioned as some of the most mind numbing that an RPG can dish up with, the majority being simple fed-ex jobs that challenges only your ability to stay awake.In the end, despite every negative thing I've brought up about this game and every negative thing I've forgot to bring up, I still enjoyed it. I enjoyed it simply because the core gameplay mechanic, the exploration, worked. And that is the most important thing for a game to accomplish. It might not be a hall of fame game in my book, but it was still a good play and a game that played to it's strengths.

content:
6, 2014
												Note: You can buy Morrowind without DRM on GoG, so I would probably recommend buying it there.Morrowind is a famously good game, but it has many factors that must be considered before touching it, these are the six that come to my mind:1. The combat system is terrible. The later games may be simplified, but the combat systems actually work in those games. This is the only real flaw I have with the game. You can defend it all you want, but the combat is terrible, and drags the entire game down, and is one of the few areas the sequels actually did better in. There are some interesting combat areas that are sadly omitted from all future instalments, such as ability, accuracy and power being directly linked to how exhausted you were.2. Difficulty. I like difficulty, but those who like Oblivion and Morrowind spoon-feeding you will hate this game. I think it makes this a real RPG, but some may disagree. However, the difficulty can be annoying, as some enemies can kill you in a single swing, or in twenty swings. It is really inconsistant.3. Navigation: As said above, the game does not hold your hand at all. There is no compass, quest markers, or other forms of game help, just your ability to ask questions and follow directions that your character puts in their journal. This once again enriches the RPG elements, but may put off those coming from its sequels.4. Oblivion and Skyrim are much easier to play. They are Action-RPG games; this has more RPG elements than its successors. This makes the game seem better for some, but can be a pulling factor to some.5. As it’s older, it naturally won't look as nice. The game has aged somewhat fine, but other games have aged more gracefully. The Morrowind Graphics Overhaul mod makes it look great though, leaving you with the now outdated gameplay mechanics.6. There is a lot of text to read. If you can't read or follow text directions, ♥♥♥♥ off.Outside of this, the game has far more focus on the lore of the Elder Scrolls universe as well. The land is far more alien than Cyrodiil or Skyrim, and the variety of environments is far wider than what is found in subsequent instalments. The world is therefore far more interesting and engaging than later instalments, and this is the final Elder Scrolls game to not include fast travel (outside of transport services), so like it or not, you will walk, sprint and jump your way across the world. The world itself outside of the environments has a lot more personality than Oblivion and Skyrim, with a much larger emphasis on what the native Dunmer consider traditional rights, introducing themes such as slavery, racism and factionalism that isn't present in such a way in any later instalments.If you are ready for the last Elder Scrolls game to focus more on RPG elements than action elements, then I'd recommend. However, if the many broken elements of this game put you off, then don't bother. Morrowind is the last Elder Scrolls game really aimed at a niche market.

content:
er 5, 2013
												TL;DR Review:Morrowind is a unique entry in the Elder Scrolls series that is just as fun, engaging and addictive as its big brothers Oblivion and Skyrim, but you will have to work a bit harder to get to the rich nougaty center.Long Review:Morrowind was the first Elder Scrolls game to be released for the Windows platform, and it's clear that Bethesda rewrote the engine from the ground up.  Gone were the problematic, randomly-generated dungeons of Daggerfall.  Now all content would be hand-created, using specialized tools to still allow the massive amounts of content that hallmark an Elder Scrolls game.The setting deserves a special mention - it's as far away from your standard generic fantasy setting as possible.  Green gives way to volcanic grey, red and purple.  You fight giant insects, dinosaur-like creatures and steampunk constructs.  Trees give way to cities built under huge mushrooms and massive stone formations.  You travel between cities tucked inside the hollowed-out shell of a giant bug.  It's almost like adventuring in an alien world instead of a fantasy one.There is a lot to do.  Over ninety dungeons to raid, four cities and thirteen towns to explore, three noble houses and four guilds to join - each of which has their own questline.  And that's not even touching the main plot, which is arguably the best one ever written for an Elder Scrolls game.Downsides?  Of course.  There's no fast travel, so you'll initially be doing a lot of walking around.  But between the silt striders (the giant bugs mentioned above), teleportation between mage's guilds, scrolls of intervention and the Mark and Recall spells, you'll eventually be jumping around Morrowind with ease, and it feels more realistic.The leveling system isn't quite as broken as the one in Oblivion but it's not as good as Skyrim.  And the progression isn't balanced well - you'll spend a long time feeling like a shmuck and then suddenly you'll be a godling.Also, because this version includes both expansion packs, early on in the game you'll be attacked by a fairly difficult enemy.  This fight can be hard for new players, but if you persevere your reward will be an excellent set of light armor that will make the rest of the early game much easier.I'm not big on mods for Morrowind, but I'd recommend the Morrowind Code Patch, especially if you play a stealthy character because it enables sneak-toggle (by default you have to hold down the sneak button for as long as you're sneaking).  It also does other silly, inconsequential things like fix a ton of crashes and savegame corruptions.  You can learn more about it and get it here:http://www.uesp.net/wiki/Tes3Mod:Morrowind_Code_PatchIf you've never played an Elder Scrolls game, I would strongly suggest you start here.  If you played Oblivion or Skyrim and want more, Morrowind will pay off for you in spades.  I highly recommend it.

content:
12, 2013
												I love Morrowind. I've played probably around 300 hours of it and there's still lots of unique quests to explore. That being said, if I take off my nostalgia glasses, there are some pretty major flaws that I feel anyone playing it for the first time today should be aware of. Breaking it down:Cons:* Combat of all types is boring. Magic/Stealth/Archery/Melee are all essentially reduced to keep-clicking-until-it-dies. On the magic side of things, the spell creation system is fun and there are lots of neat base spells to choose from, but in essence the combat itself is overly simple.* The leveling system functions fine if you just don't pay attention to it, but optimal leveling is a tedious chore. If you are the type who just can't pass up an opportunity for maximum stat gains, this might be a big detractor.* The dialogue is text based and most NPCs are just walking lore encyclopedias. The persuasion and bartering systems are laughably simple, and again, boring.* The graphics haven't aged well, though it does have a strong artistic concept at its core.* The menu interface is sub-par, but gets the job done.Pros:* Exploration is really well rewarded. Everywhere you look there's some small detail that hints at a story, or a unique artifact with interesting properties. Many of the ruins have secret entrances and places that you could easily miss.* Morrowind does a good job of making you feel like your actions have impact. It could be better, but it is satisfying when factions will hate or love you depending on what you've done, and there are many unique dialog lines based on how famous you are.* The quests are unique. Sure some of them blend together a little bit, but overall they are NOT just cookie-cutter quests. Most of them give you some insight into the world and how it works, or have some neat little twist.* You can fly. It seems so trivial but I keep coming back to this as an example of the game's overwhelming freedom. It's fun scrounging around in the early game for limited-use levitation spells or the infamous Scrolls of Icarian Flight which make you jump so high you'll certainly die on your way back down. You start out so weak but there are powerful scrolls and spells to exploit that can change the entire game... the wild variance in the power of the enemies and items you encounter is one of Morrowind's stronger points.* A final important pro is the modding community. If there are things you don't like about this game, chances are high there's a mod that can change it. In particular, I have a had good luck with graphics mod compilations and just general expansion packs. Of course, modding is not necessarily everyone's cup of tea.In summary, this game has many great features and in some ways the sense of depth and scale you get when immersed in it is unrivaled by any game since. However, it requires a certain type of gamer, (or a certain amount of modding,) to get past its unpalatable quirks and into the wonderful world beneath.EDIT: Just going to address a couple points that have come up in the comments.* Discrepancy in my playtime listed vs what I have on record with Steam. I played Morrowind in 2004 just after the GOTY edition came out, which was before it was on Steam. I later purchased it on Steam because I had lost my physical copy.* I love Morrowind yet gave it a non-recommendation. I wrote this review for the general gaming public in 2013 and I did not think it would be a good experience for the average 2013 Steam gamer because of the points listed above, hence my non-recommendation.

content:
7, 2015
												I have only 4 hrs for the steam version, but I have played this game probably more than any other and probably have close to 500 hrs logged on this game over the past decade or so.This is in terms of a role playing experience, probably the best game ever created. It is much more unforgiving, but not necessarily difficult than Oblivion and Skyrim. It is the last pure RPG in the elder scrolls series. Contrary to popular belief, this game is actually larger than both oblivion and Skyrim, before expansions. Everything except some random loot is hand placed. Everything. It is one of the most immersive experiences ever. There is little voiced dialogue but I feel it is made up by the massive amounts of DEPTH that is in the text conversations and just the sheer amount of background and lore and history you get from speaking to NPCs.Story wise in terms of pure "Feeling important like a hero factor" Morrowind stomps both Skyrim and Oblivion. Oblivion you are second fiddle to Martin septim. In Skyrim, literally nobody gives a damn about you or your importance, your goal is so ridiculously simple (Slay alduin and the dragons) and has so little depth to the story. Morrowind's story is so epic, and you feel like you are truly doing something of great and supreme importance, even though the impact was so much smaller than the end goals in Oblivion, and Skyrim in terms of the overall story of Tamriel.This game has not aged well, but luckily has more mods than oblivion and skyrim put together including several freaking amazing visual mods that basically make it prettier than either of them. The combat is lackluster and mostly just dependant on your stats, which honestly the most efficent way to level up is to train from Npcs simply because otherwise it can be a bit of a pain.  If you play this game you will understand how "casualized" and gutted skyrim especially is. It's still an excellent, amazing game don't get me wrong, but it doesn't hold a candle to the amount of depth that is contained in probably the greatest game ever made in the history of mankind.

er 24, 2016
												This is by far the best open world game I have ever played. People moan about the initial fighting system, but in my oppinion, the system works: your base attributes and skill set is clearly reflecting your level. When you are level 1, you can not take on even level 5 monsters and enemies, because you are simply to weak. This is not faulty gameplay, this is just a game that refuses to hold your hand. On the other hand, as you reach level 20 and beyond you will start to feel like a God, as suddenly nothing will stand in your way or slow you down as you plow through dungeons and mission like an irresistable force! This game is highly recomendable. I have played it since it came out decades ago and recently purchased it again (to make it work with windows 10) and I still find new stuff, even after thousands of hours of pplay (litterally). Epic!

												I have played this game since it came out in 2002, and it continues to be my personal favorite of The Elder Scrolls series. The story is compelling, and actually draws you into the world unlike in Skyrim, and Oblivion. Don't get me wrong that Skyrim and Oblivion don't draw you in. They do, just not on the same scale.Advancing in a Faction requires you to be proficent in their favored skills, not just doing the quests.There are NO limits to what you can do if you really think about it. Have you ever wanted to make a ring or amulet that lets you Levitate forever? This game engine lets you do that, you just have to make it yourself.Do you want to use the soul of a God to power a pair of slippers? Go for it.Have I replayed this game over and over? Of course.Do I recommend that you play this through before playing Skywind? Absolutely.

												Morrowind is a very well-made RPG that does not hold your hand. Some Morrowind features such as map notes and a superior bartering system bring out the flaws of the other games in the series.If you have played the newer games in the series before Morrowind; the lack of fast travel and quest markers will be obvious as soon as you enter the introduction.You will be forced to ask locals for directions, you will add notes to the map to remind yourself of certain details of the world and Morrowind is more satisfying game because of it and that is one of the aspects that makes Morrowind so enjoyable: Satisfaction that you have achieved everything by yourself.So take a carriage and then a boat, east, to Morrowind, you won't regret it.10/10

content:
er 15, 2014
												I first played this game in 2004. When I saw it I was blown away that I could be who I wanna be and go where I wanna go. And that was exactly what I got back then when I played it. Im sure I put over 1000 hours into it easily by now.Well i recently picked this game up again. Added the graphical overhaul 3.0 and its definatelly stunning in comparrison to the original so highly recommend getting that. 100%Well I definately love Skyrim to death and I think the combat in Oblivion is good but the rest of the game is Ehhh... okay.. i guess. At best.But the way the world of Morrowind it self is crafted is like no other open world RPG befor or since. Just the level of love they put into every area and every detail is fantastic. The world it self is what grips me in these type of games and this world is everything but "just slapped together". Its very detailed, it has enough dungeons to explore around every corner and I love that when im exploring I can open a chest and potentially I could find anything. Kinda like Diablo. Loot finding is awesome. Great variaty. Not just the same kinda things over and over like in the other Elder Scrolls games.Combat may not be for everyone though and I can understand that. Its alittle dull. But if your willing to get used to it you will definately have a good time.  For me personally even when it comes to playability today this is my favorite Elder Scrolls game. Though I also love Skyrim as well. This is the perfect "in the middle" of the series game, in that i mean, it has the action and feel of the newer ones while keeping it classic RPG like Daggerfall and Arena. Its the perfect middle man.But The reason I recomend it most of all is beacuse of the world of Morrowind it self. To me its the best crafted and most lovingly detailed Open World RPG of all time. Its kinda like they relized the possibilitys of creating and open world and they persued it passionately as hell. It is definately a trail blazer game that was built with a passion.9.7/10

content:
ry 10
												I will always say that Morrowind is the most Elder Scrolls that the series will ever be. This game has more depth, character, and atmosphere than any other game in the series. Here are a few things that I love about Morrowind: Interesting and Unique Setting and Lore Memorable, Impactful Atmosphere Clever, Well-Developed Writing Difficult, Thought-Provoking Quests Bucketloads of ContentAnd bucketloads is almost an understatement of how much game Morrowind has to offer. This game's depth isn't even scratched by Oblivion or Skyrim. Morrowind has more armor, more skills, more classes, more weapons and weapon types, more dialogue, more of just about everything. The game's skill system isn't limited in as many ways either, so you can push your character to insane power. This game is an art piece that just needs to be experienced by serious fans. But that's not to say that it is objectively the best game in the series, and it is definately not the most accessible. The game almost requires a different mindset for playing than Oblivion or Skyrim requires. It's slow, atmospheric, difficult, old, and a little unfair at times. Many newer Elder Scrolls fans are turned off by a number of factors present in Morrowind: RNG (Random Number Generator) Based Combat Slower Pace Lack of Voiced Dialogue Less User-Friendly Quests, Interface, and Controls Awkward, Aged GraphicsThese things may be difficult to get past when you first get into it (especially for a Skyrim player), but the game has so much to offer once you push past them.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2015
												Throughout the years, I've put maybe 4500 hours into this game, more than any other game, over the course of three lost and rebought discs, as well as the Steam edition once I stopped putting optical drives into my computers. I still have the Cliffracer screech as my alarm in the morning. Doesn't fail to wake me up.To me, this is the highlight of the Elder Scrolls franchise. I realize a lot of it is nostalgia - when this came out there was nothing about it that wasn't revolutionary in scope. Oh, I remember the days when my mates would outright whine for days about not being able to run the game well, after they saw what it was supposed to look like on my first proper bleeding-edge gaming PC.Off the back of its combat system, the game got a few moderate reviews, even back in 2002. Which is understandable as this game is something as rare as a PC game that was ported to console rather than the other way around. However, as a pen & paper role playing gamer I always enjoyed the combat and never understood the problem people had with it. I was simply predisposed to suspend my disbelief before I even began.Even today, with the graphical mods to Morrowind that are available, I have still not been able to make Oblivion look better than Morrowind. Modded DirectX 9 Morrowind just flat out looks better and more atmospheric.The soundtrack is up there in my top 5, maybe second behind Age of Conan: Hyborian Adventures, just in front of the Monkey Island franchise. Jeremy Soule's best work, and such a great compliment to exploration and discovery. Apart from aforementioned Age of Conan soundtrack, I have never been more motivated to explore just because of a soundtrack. And when you hear that Cliffracer screech and the descent of timpanis, you know ♥♥♥♥ is going down.Thank god we had spears back then. Nothing like a 1.5 reach modifier against Cliffracers.A modder's perspective:The game is infinitely moddable - more so than the newer TES titles. It is just more accessible and powerful. There's no need to add empty voice .mp3 to a mod just so the dialogue won't skip along on its merry way. There is no convoluted AI pathing and waypoint micromanagement just to script an NPC to move somewhere. And the scripting language in Morrowind is just downright simpler and more intuitive than most notably Skyrim.For these reasons, Morrowind still to this day has 5-10 new mods being posted every day, and a live community. Additionally, because of how easy it is to turn idea to practice, the amount and quality of quest mods is tenfold that of especially Skyrim. If you want ACTUAL CONTENT from mods, and not just blinging out your character or anime mods, Morrowind is hands down the game you should get.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 11
												Morrowind won't hold your hand. It's dark and deep and the main story is much more complex than in Skyrim or Oblivion. There’s no “good” or “bad” here and it’s virtually impossible to make everyone love you. And this makes the game’s world truly believable.Morrowind simply asks you to take your time, get into the lore, explore the world, understand its politics and history. It's a game that's hard to get into... but very satisfying when you do. Definitely not for everyone. Still, the atmosphere, the main story, the side quests, the politics, the alchemy and enchanting system and the overall freedom that Morrowind gives you make up for all its flaws.If you're looking for an outlandish open-world RPG experience in a dark cruel world... I'd definitely recommend Morrowind. Here you need to earn your respect, slowly build up your reputation and only then you may truly enjoy it as a power fantasy game. And trust me, it'll give you much more satisfaction than being called the Dragonborn after 30 or 60 minutes of gameplay.

content:
er 27, 2015
												TES III: Morrowind is not a RPG, it is an experience and a milestone.The moment when you step outside the ship and the soundtracks kicks in, doesn't only mark the beginning of your adventure, but the beginning of a genre that defined the future of RPGs.Every NPC encountered, every quest or enemy, they all hold a special place in our memories and this is what makes Morrowind such a great game.For many gamers this is the first played TES episode, and probably this is the reason that made us purchase the Steam version once again: the first TES is like your first love, it is unforgettable and incomparable.I remember receiving it as a Christmas present in the early 2002, along with my Xbox; I remember the Christmas holidays spent trying to figure out how to properly play it as I felt amazed by the open world in front of my eyes. And now that Chirstmas is nearing (27 Novemeber 2015 as I am writing this review), I can feel the very same excitement, the sensation of awe when I arrived once again in Balmora, the thrill of having taken down an enemy after countless missed hits, and yes, even the terrible sensation of annoyance everytime a Cliff Racer approaches me.Honestly, despide all the wonderful mods user created, I refuse to enhance this experience, as I wouldn't feel it original and genuine. My advice is to play Morrowind as it is, and afterwards, perhaps, try out all the user created content.Do not wait any longer, grab it already, you n'wah!

3, 2015
												Morrowind is by far the most "true" RPG of the Elder Scrolls games on steam. It is a very different game than Oblivion or Skyrim, but ultimately whether or not you enjoy the game depends on your liking for more traditional RPG elements vs. the action-RPG elements of the newer elder scrolls games. However, if you just want a cool setting to explore, this game will certainly satisfy, as the world is really an interesting and unique place.  It also happens to have my favorite music of the ES games. If you can deal with dated graphics and slightly dated gameplay, it's certainly worth your time. 8.6/10
