content:
7, 2016
												This game is what Skyrim promises to be. I love all the Bethesda games, even Fallout 4, but there's no denying this is the best Elder Scrolls made IMO. Daggerfall is too archaic for me to want to pick up, and while I recommend the Morrowind Overhaul project, I'm playing through for my first time using only a mod to fix the resolution and loving it. You can craft spells with EIGHT DIFFERENT EFFECTS. Want a spell mixing multiple elements and area of effect damage? You can do it. Want to summon 8 Daedric Beings with the press of a button? You can do it. Want to create a spell that heals as much as it damages, allowind you to indefinitely practice your magic on one enemy? You. Can. Do. It. All the systems in this game are about as deep as that, and alchemy requires FOUR different machines to properly do it. The two biggest barriers to entry are the graphics and combat. Morrowind Overhaul fixes that completely so that's squared away. The combat is purely stat based; I do more damage with a mid range sword than the best most OP axe in the game, because you'll miss your swings with a weapon you have no knowledge of how to use. Also WATCH YOUR FATIGUE. % chance you hit is based on how much fatigue you have, don't be like those dumbasses who mash left mouse and wonder why they miss every swing.Pros- In depth lore and a wide variety of topics to ask NPCs about.The best magic system in any game I've played. Free form quests- I have a sword powered by the soul of a god I slew. Nobody told me to do that, Morrowind merely provides the weapon (Daedric Shortsword) the soul (not gonna spoil which god) and the means (in depth enchanting system) to do it. Wide variety of locales and quests. Good storytelling that isn't always spoonfed to you. To cure vampirism without looking it up online, you need to read a couple of books and figure it out yourself. As far as I know, it's impossible any other way besides discovering it by dumb luck or google.Truly an RPG. Very easy to stick to your characters beliefs, unlike in Skyrim where the story makes you a good guy no matter what you do because you saved the world from Alduin.Cons-Somewhat obtuse mechanics. Once they're learned they're badass, but hard to do so. I recommend looking up how to do alchemy, enchanting, etc. as the game expects you to have an instruction manual.Some bugs. Morrowind Overhaul fixes thousands though.Personal Preference- I think having to read to figure stuff out without the game just telling you is awesome. Some might not.No quest markers. You get directions, and late game are in unexplored areas and have to go off of handwritten maps. Conclusion- 10/10 best RPG I've ever played. Quite a challenge, but if you're up to it, it's the most rewarding game I've ever played.

9, 2015
												Now that i beat it for the second time i can comfortably review this game. imma keep it short and sweet. Pros!  +Vast attribute system [lots of different ways to level up and customize your character if you wanna make your class.]  +Long and engaging story with a lore deeper than the rest of the Elder Scrolls games.  +Enchanting weapons and armor and accessories has never felt better, so many different ways to customize as long as you have means to  +Vast open world with many secrets to discover. a very diverse landscape indeed which is probably why i didnt favor skyrim that much seeing as how it was smaller and less diverse with a few secrets.  +a soundtrack unlike any other, absolutely beautiful.  +Combat is quite unique. although it may not be the best, spell creation and badass enchanted weapons do make up. Cons.  -Not very good looking in terms of asthetics, didnt age too well. [strongly reccomend getting the Overhaul 3.0]  -Combat is not the best. [refer to the last Pro]  -Requires alot of reading to get through it. [not nessarily a bad thing, just pointing out how most people wont like it as opposed to skyrims quest markers. git gud] Overall : 9/10 Definately one of the most unforgettable Rpg Experiences out there to date. till this day i have not played an RPG that could engage me like Morrowind did. I reccomend giving this game a try if you a hardcore fan of the series.

29, 2014
												This has to be one of my favourite games ever. Yes it's graphics are dated, and the gameplay can be a ♥♥♥♥♥ if you're only used to newer games, but trust me, Morrowind is amazing. The atmosphere of the game is, in my opinion, almost unrivaled. Small things like the sound of a siltstrider in the distance or the sandstorms blowing through towns completely immerse you in the world of Morrowind. While the story features no real character developement like some newer games (and duh, it's a western RPG they never do anyway) the main narrative is epic, there is no other word for it. Bits and pieces of the story come together slowly and little things fall into place as you do side quests, Morrowind lets you live out one of the best realised fantasy worlds ever, without the irritating limits on choices that are enforced in Skyrim and Oblivion. So seriously, buy this game, and get on to the Elder Scrolls website and get all the free addons.

content:
er 14, 2015
												Morrowind is and always will be a true masterpeice that is the crown jewel of classic RPGS. Yes, I said it, the CROWN JEWEL, sorry Occarina of Time! Morrowind is not for the faint-hearted kid fans of Skyrim who play it like it's a hack and slash. It is not for picky, complaining adults who point every little fault out and refuse to enjoy games for what they are. Morrowind is for hardcore RPG players, the people who can just get lost in the world for days at a time wanting to find every city and do every quest. It's for those of us who can sit down, start up the game, and find our way through with no in-game quest markers at all, instead using strategy, creativity, and logic. And above all, Morrowind is for true Elder Scrolls fans, with history books scattered around the world and a story that ingeniously weaves it's way deep into the past and present of the Elder Scrolls timeline. Overall, if you are a hack and slash fan of Skyrim and not the whole franchise, who will pick apart a game just to find something to complain about, this game is not for you, so don't buy it. Period. If you are an RPG gamer and a true fan of the Elder Scrolls, get Morrowind NOW. Seriously, get it now, you are missing out on a great game!

er 15, 2014
												I first played this game in 2004. When I saw it I was blown away that I could be who I wanna be and go where I wanna go. And that was exactly what I got back then when I played it. Im sure I put over 1000 hours into it easily by now.Well i recently picked this game up again. Added the graphical overhaul 3.0 and its definatelly stunning in comparrison to the original so highly recommend getting that. 100%Well I definately love Skyrim to death and I think the combat in Oblivion is good but the rest of the game is Ehhh... okay.. i guess. At best.But the way the world of Morrowind it self is crafted is like no other open world RPG befor or since. Just the level of love they put into every area and every detail is fantastic. The world it self is what grips me in these type of games and this world is everything but "just slapped together". Its very detailed, it has enough dungeons to explore around every corner and I love that when im exploring I can open a chest and potentially I could find anything. Kinda like Diablo. Loot finding is awesome. Great variaty. Not just the same kinda things over and over like in the other Elder Scrolls games.Combat may not be for everyone though and I can understand that. Its alittle dull. But if your willing to get used to it you will definately have a good time.  For me personally even when it comes to playability today this is my favorite Elder Scrolls game. Though I also love Skyrim as well. This is the perfect "in the middle" of the series game, in that i mean, it has the action and feel of the newer ones while keeping it classic RPG like Daggerfall and Arena. Its the perfect middle man.But The reason I recomend it most of all is beacuse of the world of Morrowind it self. To me its the best crafted and most lovingly detailed Open World RPG of all time. Its kinda like they relized the possibilitys of creating and open world and they persued it passionately as hell. It is definately a trail blazer game that was built with a passion.9.7/10

content:
ry 14
												Morrowind has to be one of the most aged, arduous games you could ever play. But it defined a whole generation and brought the Elder Scrolls series into the modern light. Combat is clunky but you can really feel your character grow as you begin to hit more things and face much tougher enemies. The Elder Scrolls has always included a massive world to explore but I think no game like it has ever invoked the true freedom of a players decisions like this one has. The Spells and Enchantment's make anything possible in this game. Whereas other games in the series and in other open worlds have set resistrictions on the player. Morrowind's greatest strength is the ability to play how you want. You can enchant and craft leviation relics and spells to complely avoid areas, make items which drain the life of users who wear them (making killing civilians without being noticed a breeze) and practically create anything you can think of. Even the main story is something that can be overlooked or ruined completely if that is what you want to do. Despite all of its flaws in gameplay, that is what makes Morrowind so special for me even today. It has problems and I certainly don't think its the best RPG ever made. But it's a captivating game with a rich lore and a true sense of freedom that even games today have trouble creating.

ry 10
												I will always say that Morrowind is the most Elder Scrolls that the series will ever be. This game has more depth, character, and atmosphere than any other game in the series. Here are a few things that I love about Morrowind: Interesting and Unique Setting and Lore Memorable, Impactful Atmosphere Clever, Well-Developed Writing Difficult, Thought-Provoking Quests Bucketloads of ContentAnd bucketloads is almost an understatement of how much game Morrowind has to offer. This game's depth isn't even scratched by Oblivion or Skyrim. Morrowind has more armor, more skills, more classes, more weapons and weapon types, more dialogue, more of just about everything. The game's skill system isn't limited in as many ways either, so you can push your character to insane power. This game is an art piece that just needs to be experienced by serious fans. But that's not to say that it is objectively the best game in the series, and it is definately not the most accessible. The game almost requires a different mindset for playing than Oblivion or Skyrim requires. It's slow, atmospheric, difficult, old, and a little unfair at times. Many newer Elder Scrolls fans are turned off by a number of factors present in Morrowind: RNG (Random Number Generator) Based Combat Slower Pace Lack of Voiced Dialogue Less User-Friendly Quests, Interface, and Controls Awkward, Aged GraphicsThese things may be difficult to get past when you first get into it (especially for a Skyrim player), but the game has so much to offer once you push past them.

content:
er 27, 2015
												TES III: Morrowind is not a RPG, it is an experience and a milestone.The moment when you step outside the ship and the soundtracks kicks in, doesn't only mark the beginning of your adventure, but the beginning of a genre that defined the future of RPGs.Every NPC encountered, every quest or enemy, they all hold a special place in our memories and this is what makes Morrowind such a great game.For many gamers this is the first played TES episode, and probably this is the reason that made us purchase the Steam version once again: the first TES is like your first love, it is unforgettable and incomparable.I remember receiving it as a Christmas present in the early 2002, along with my Xbox; I remember the Christmas holidays spent trying to figure out how to properly play it as I felt amazed by the open world in front of my eyes. And now that Chirstmas is nearing (27 Novemeber 2015 as I am writing this review), I can feel the very same excitement, the sensation of awe when I arrived once again in Balmora, the thrill of having taken down an enemy after countless missed hits, and yes, even the terrible sensation of annoyance everytime a Cliff Racer approaches me.Honestly, despide all the wonderful mods user created, I refuse to enhance this experience, as I wouldn't feel it original and genuine. My advice is to play Morrowind as it is, and afterwards, perhaps, try out all the user created content.Do not wait any longer, grab it already, you n'wah!

ber 7, 2014
												Morrowind's greatest triumph is that it crafts a distinctly unique fantasy world, from its various cultures and politics to its dwellings, landscapes, and species.  There is a great deal to discover and an epic story to be experienced - one that still stands as one of the best, even all these years later.However, the game is not without its flaws.  In particular, combat and its related skills are a bit unrefined.  For example, you won't be able to hit anything with melee attacks until you raise your melee skill, which is only raised by successfully hitting things.  Luckily, this game was very popular and you can find many mods to get around the aspects of the game that aren't up to modern snuff.If you have the time and see what fantasy can be like when it isn't just piggy-backing off of Tolkien, play this game!

er 30, 2014
												In my opinion: The best Elder Scrolls game available. Its almost the polar opposite of titles like Skyrim. Morrowind encourages exploration and flatout tells you to deviate from the main story to become more experienced and come back when you think you're more prepared to progress. There is no fast travel, only Striders which are basically buses. And there are no quest markers. The game instead gives you directions which you then write down in your journal. Personally I had a much better time trying to figure out how to get places based on hints and directions than just walking mindlessly towards a beacon on my map. This game is flawless, a masterpiece. Granted it does take an hour or so to get past the "terrible" graphics. And you may one to get an HD overhaul mod or two. But with the previous set aside, RPG/Adventure games can't get any better than this.Pros:-Blinding nastolgia-Amazing exploration-Beautiful world design-Stunning character design-Easy to use UI-Great storyCons:-YOU RUN SOOOO DAMN SLOW!!!-Its incredibly hard to do a brute character. (magic is your best bet)

content:
ry 28, 2015
												Just as a side note, I have never played an Elder Scrolls game before Morrowind. I have never played another one since I bought it on December 24, 2014 either.  Anyways, Morrowind is an open world RPG game, and probably the Elder Scrolls game the brought the Elder Scrolls franchise into the public's eye. Many people claim that the reason people still play this game today is because of "nostalgia" and they say that it's outdated. I can seriously say that this is completely false. I can say this with all honesty because this game was made only one year after I was born, as I was born in 2001 and this game was made in 2002. I'll go through a couple of major catagories of this game and give some details on each one in this part of the review. Graphics This section does not deal with the enviroment, but with the actually way things look. While this game was made in 2002, the graphics are actually decent. While yes, they have a low polygon count and are rather structured, it still gets the job done. There is still a lot of artistic talent going on here, the art really shines in my opinion. And honestly, graphics can be completely redone by MGSO. I really am fine with a game having O-K graphics, so I'm going to give this section a7/10 Gameplay If you're not totally new to the gaming world, you've probably heard something about Morrowind's combat and how bad it is. And truely, it is not very interesting. Stealth, magic, melee, ranged. Nope. But this game isn't about combat. It's about exploration, questing, collecting, and talking. Sure, there is some combat, but it really doesn't play as huge of a part as other RPG games I've played. Anyways, the gameplay is fun. Exploration is very well rewarded, and there are lots of places to visit and people to talk to. Also, there is so much to do in this game. I'm 120 hours in and I haven't even come close to finishing the main quest, and I have about 5 characters so far (four of whom havent started the main quest at all). I am going to give this section a 9/10  Story and NPCs I'm lumping all of these together because they have a lot in common. The story to this game I think is actually very interesting. While it sort of follows the classic "an ancient evil has awoken" story, it's done in a very unique way in which you can relate to both "sides" and in this case there are actually very many sides. More on that later. Now onto NPCs. The NPCs are pretty bland, with a few exceptions. They have generic answers and things to talk about, and none of the dialoge is voiced. This can be sort of fixed with mods, but I'd still give NPCs a 6/10and the story a 10/10 because it truely is a fantastic story. Setting The setting may be this game's strongest part. You could also call this part the enviroment. The world of Morrowind is a very alien one. About the only thing that you might recognize is a rat when speaking about Fauna, or some grass and tress if you're talking about Flora. Everything is so different and stranged, and it's rather intimidating stepping out of the first building and being greeted by a giant mushroom (and Fargoth...). Also, the history behind everything is really awesome. Just about every cave you explore has a stroy that you can peice together from things that you find in it, it's quite facinating.If you haven't read much about TES lore, Morrowind is the land of the Dunmer, or dark elves and was also once home of the Chimer and the Dwemer. The setting and history is so very interesting and I really get engrossed in it. I could rave on for a really long while just talking about this, but I'll spare you.  Expansions The expansions to Morrowind are pretty awesome, too. Bloodmoon transports you to Solstheim, an island just north of Morrowind where the Legion has just set up fort and some pioneers are trying to set up a village (which you get to help build, by the way). I'm not going to spoil a lot but lets just say  FIRST PERSON LYCANTHROPY Tribunal takes you to Mournhold, the capital of Morrowind. Now I haven't started this one yet, because it's not supposed to make sense if you haven't done the main quest, but It's supposed to be really awesome. You get to meet Sotha Sil! (sorta) I'm going to give the expansions a 9/10----------Now that I've covered the major points I'll cover a couple of minor ones.MusicFantastic. There is not a lot of it, but the stuff the you do have is amazing and really captures the essence of Morrowind. Plus, the Elder Scrolls theme comes from this game. There are also lots of mods that give the game more music like the things already in the vanilla game. I'll give this section 9/10 (one point off because there isn't as much music as I might have liked. Speaking of mods...Mods!There are so many mods! The community has been pumping them out since 2002, so there are a boatload of mods out there. MGSO, Sotha Sil Expanded, Starfire's NPCs, Tamriel Rebuilt, just so many. The community for this game is truly fantastic (and not pervy like Skyrim's or Oblivion's).10/10PerformanceThis game should perform well on any computer made after 2007. I can't afford a nice PC at this time, and even on my 2011 laptop, I get 25-30 fps at all time with Medium Settings on MGSO. You shouldn't worry about your computer being able to take this game, especially if you have a nice one.9/10 Conclusion All in all, Morrowind is a fantastic game. I recomment it to anyone who likes RPG games. And don't be fooled by the age of the game. Even vanilla Morrowind is so much better than all of the stuff they are pumping out these days. Thanks for reading, and I hope that this inspired you to buy this game. I hope you enjoyed my review!I give this game a  10/10 3000th Review for this game, yay.

2015
												8/10 now after 13 years of aging, but 10/10 for its time.  This being said only because I'm taking into consideration its mechanics compared to all other games old and new.  Granted, it still has mechanics and gameplay aspects that are still unique to this day.  Though disregarding its modern day competitors, the environment, story, lore, and immersion of this game still hold up beautifully.  Any fan of The Elder Scrolls series absolutely need to play this game.  It enhances the story and immersion of the newer games in the series considerably (especially the Solstheim DLC in Skyrim.)  I got this game after playing Oblivion and Skyrim and still had a blast playing it.  This game is truly a masterpiece and gem of its time.

content:
ry 13, 2016
												Spent a lot of my time in OpenMW rather than vanilla Morrowind, so my steam play time is relatively lower than my actual hours played. Open MW only updates the game engine, making it far more stable, nothing else, so i do know the game and its quirks well.Morrowind does not infact take place within Morrowind, It takes place on the island of Vvardenfell, I direct you to Tamriel Rebuilt for full Morrowind land mass.More in depth than Skyrim in terms of enchanting, magics, weaponry and interesting character backstories and a fantasticly built up world and of course, the NEED for stats and decent thought on how you distribute them.Story starts similarly to Oblivion and Skyrim... and most TES games with the old prisoner shenanigans.Combat is intensely complex, needing relative knowledge of how the Races and Classes will effect how your character plays during the first say around 5-10 levels when EVERYTHING can mess up your day.Not as pretty as Skyrim in terms of the games appearance, but at the heart the game has more soul, Though the looks can be potentially fixed with MGSO (go check it out if your unsure).Still to this day I would willingly pay $40 for this as there is potentially tons of replayability, even in terms of main storylines.ALL NPC's can be killed, yep even so called "Essentials", you kill a main quest character. Good job, find another way to do the quest and at worst, thats it, quest over, gg well played go screw over someone else now.A lot of people, will be put off by A- the graphics B- the combat system, C- how the game treats you like ♥♥♥♥ at low levels.The game does not care if you are roleplaying an uber hero, until you have actually achieved something in the eyes of Vvardenfells people. You are not a majestic hero with power flowing out of every orifice on your person. You're no one, N'wah, Outlander. A person who does not know Vvardenfell, unwanted by the populace of Dunmer, those who do want you there don't want you... youu are there by the commands of their superiors. You are a blade of grass upon a huge field, no one, nothing, no heroic deeds to your name, no well made gear on your person, your privilige is you are allowed to tread upon Vvardenfells pathways, your only reward is the gear you fight for and scrape from dust and corpses.Uses ye olde fantasy utility of only silver and magical weapons can harm Ghosts, Daedra, etc...Moddable, but with great delicacy.Frustrating at first, but grows on you, slowly.I hope to the nine divines Bethesda leave MW alone, as I know for a fact, they will remove the dice rolls hits and ridiculusly OP enchants, scrolls and potion possibilities. On par with the Witcher 3's detailing in the world, On par with Skyrims modding community, On par with the Nostalia of Baldurs Gate. Ridiculously cheap for what it actuallt is.The Elder Scrolls at it's finest.Morrowind.

content:
ry 7
												Hands down my  favorite game ever made. Don' t let the time that Steam shows fool you. I've played countless hours on the original Xbox and the non Steam version.Don't get me wrong, I love Oblivion and Skyrim, but in my own opinion they do not even come close to competing with the detail this games brings. If you're looking for more fluid combat and an overall wayyyy easier gaming experience then go play either of those games. They are both great as you probably know. I myself don't like having a magic compass point me to my next quest. It makes you miss a lot of detail and cool things to be found if you're just following your compass from quest to quest. The lore and story in this game alone makes it worth the playthrough. The amount of content provided via NPC/Books is unbelievable. Once you play this game for a couple of hours you will overlook the dated combat and fall in love. Also, if you like more modernized graphics I recommend downloading MGSO. It updates many aspects of the game without straying from the vanilla experience. Buy it. You won't be disappointed.

content:
ry 15
												Having played over 10,000 hours of this game since its release purchasing multiple copies over the last 15 years I would recommend this game to anyone. To me this is by far the best elder scrolls game ever made it truly felt like an entirely open world rpg that you could literally go out after making your PC and explore with very little boundries. The game was beautiful when it came out and the support from the mod communities continues to make it so. Morrowind a game well worth investing in. The story is rich the world is alien and unique the choices are nigh endless. If i where to introduce anyone to an rpg THIS IS THAT GAME. As far as the elder scrolls series I would always start anyone right here with Morrowind. If you are looking for an EPIC game that you can invist hours in you have found it. I hope that one day Bathsalts Studios will try to re-master Morrowind but leave all of the features the game has be as they are. That will never happen but i know the mod communities will keep this game alive for years to come.

content:
ry 13, 2016
												Spent a lot of my time in OpenMW rather than vanilla Morrowind, so my steam play time is relatively lower than my actual hours played. Open MW only updates the game engine, making it far more stable, nothing else, so i do know the game and its quirks well.Morrowind does not infact take place within Morrowind, It takes place on the island of Vvardenfell, I direct you to Tamriel Rebuilt for full Morrowind land mass.More in depth than Skyrim in terms of enchanting, magics, weaponry and interesting character backstories and a fantasticly built up world and of course, the NEED for stats and decent thought on how you distribute them.Story starts similarly to Oblivion and Skyrim... and most TES games with the old prisoner shenanigans.Combat is intensely complex, needing relative knowledge of how the Races and Classes will effect how your character plays during the first say around 5-10 levels when EVERYTHING can mess up your day.Not as pretty as Skyrim in terms of the games appearance, but at the heart the game has more soul, Though the looks can be potentially fixed with MGSO (go check it out if your unsure).Still to this day I would willingly pay $40 for this as there is potentially tons of replayability, even in terms of main storylines.ALL NPC's can be killed, yep even so called "Essentials", you kill a main quest character. Good job, find another way to do the quest and at worst, thats it, quest over, gg well played go screw over someone else now.A lot of people, will be put off by A- the graphics B- the combat system, C- how the game treats you like ♥♥♥♥ at low levels.The game does not care if you are roleplaying an uber hero, until you have actually achieved something in the eyes of Vvardenfells people. You are not a majestic hero with power flowing out of every orifice on your person. You're no one, N'wah, Outlander. A person who does not know Vvardenfell, unwanted by the populace of Dunmer, those who do want you there don't want you... youu are there by the commands of their superiors. You are a blade of grass upon a huge field, no one, nothing, no heroic deeds to your name, no well made gear on your person, your privilige is you are allowed to tread upon Vvardenfells pathways, your only reward is the gear you fight for and scrape from dust and corpses.Uses ye olde fantasy utility of only silver and magical weapons can harm Ghosts, Daedra, etc...Moddable, but with great delicacy.Frustrating at first, but grows on you, slowly.I hope to the nine divines Bethesda leave MW alone, as I know for a fact, they will remove the dice rolls hits and ridiculusly OP enchants, scrolls and potion possibilities. On par with the Witcher 3's detailing in the world, On par with Skyrims modding community, On par with the Nostalia of Baldurs Gate. Ridiculously cheap for what it actuallt is.The Elder Scrolls at it's finest.Morrowind.

content:
er 24, 2013
												I'm going to open with pointing out my bias, because I played and loved this game endlessly on XBox back when it came out. Objectively, the graphics are very dated, and the gameplay does feel a little clunky. However if you're any fan of more classic RPG's, you need to give this game a look. Before Oblivion's more medieval landscape (Shivering Isles exheunt) and before Skyrim's Canada, Morrowind built a beautiful fantasy landscape, filled with spectacular creatures, varied characters, dwarven mechanations, and original quests.Technically speaking, the sound and graphics aren't much to speak of (though the music is adventurous, and really ups the experience). There is not much voice acting to speak of in most of this game, instead Bethesda opted for text boxes to save space. However, this opens the door for so much lore, and flavor text (which is important, damnit!) that this feels like the best crafted version of the Elder Scrolls universe. The game isn't levelled like it's predecessors, the world stays as it is, and you start out pretty weak. But it pushes you to be strong, and if you put the time in, you can overcome every challenge. There isn't a lot of emphasis on balance, because like a classic RPG, this game doesn't hold your hand. There isn't a compass to help you find quest points, instead you have a journal which subjectively directs you to your quest goal. For example, "The cave is north of Seyda Neen, a bit past the bridge on the river." It feels like a real adventure, going through it.If I were to price it: 30-Full price due to the age. But the game now can be found for incredibly cheap, I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a hard RPG experience.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 24, 2016
												Morrowind has long been one of the best of the best.  What makes it so are the setting and the freedom.  I got into the franchise with Skyrim, but Morrowind is truly its pinnacle.  Sad to say we are unlikely to see anything like it as long as the corporate higher-ups at Bethesda see the Skyrim model as a safer bet.  Sure, Skyrim is prettier, and many people prefer its combat, but it just can't do as much, not even with mods.Really, I think what turns most people off the combat system isn't that it's based somewhat in RNG, it's that it's based somewhat in RNG but there's no animations showing what happened, leading to ridiculous situations where people go "I stabbed that rat in the face at point blank range and missed!" rather than "It dodged again?!  I guess rats are really fast..."  I think the latter is enough more immersive that many people would be able to ignore it...so long as they know WHY they're missing (usually low fatigue because they're running everywhere).  While there doesn't seem to be a mod to accomplish this now, when the open-source engine OpenMW hits version 1.0 and a full release, this kind of mod should be entirely possible, among a host of other options, such as natively working on Linux.  (As of this review, OpenMW is on version 0.40 -- perfectly playable, but somewhat buggy and doesn't work with all mods.)  There are, however, mods to make the combat like that in Skyrim and Oblivion -- I recommend the mod Oblivion-like Combat, which, as far as I know, is still only found on the official Bethesda forums.Finding mods for Morrowind can take a bit more searching than it does for Skyrim.  Skyrim mods are mostly consolidated on the Nexus, with a few exceptions.  Morrowind mods on the Nexus are few and far between.  Most are found on Morrowind Modding History, Great House Fliggerty, or the personal websites of the authors.  MMH in particular is an archive for all the mods formerly hosted on sites like Planet Elder Scrolls and ElricM which have gone down over the years.  You can find some truly impressive and interesting stuff there and the quantity swamps the Nexus, with almost four times as many mods uploaded.  Between GFH, MMH, the Nexus and all the other small sites out there hosting a handful of mods, I'm pretty sure there are more Morrowind mods available for download than Skyrim, and they're capable of affecting a lot more.  Much of what's hardcoded in Skyrim's engine is able to be altered in Morrowind's, and because of the way the engine processes them as well as the scripting language used, scripts are both safer to use and more versatile.  Beyond that, for things that ARE hardcoded, we have external utilities like the Morrowind Code Patch to make the changes we need, in addition to the script extender and others.The other enormous advantage Morrowind has over its sequels is its setting, which is strange, and alien, and very good at telling a story through the world itself.  Morrowind is also where most of the series' interesting lore comes from.  If you don't know how anyone can care about TES lore and haven't played Morrowind, that's probably why.  One of their major writers for the game has written stuff that makes it look like he can't possibly be sober, and yet it somehow works.  If you don't know what I'm talking about, look up Michael Kirkbride.  The man is some strange variety of storytelling genius, even if he doesn't appear to be at first glance.Other majorly good things about Morrowind include its main quest, which is probably the highest-quality out of the series  (by a very long way if you're only comparing it to Skyrim, and a bit less if you also include Oblivion).  There's just something special about getting dropped on Vvardenfell with not a coin to your name and no idea what you're doing or why you're there, and working your way up to godlike power so you can face down a terrible threat to all of Tamriel...Or is he?  Delve into the lore and the backstories, and you find it's not all so cut-and-dry.  Are those who would see the armies arrayed in secret shrines and ancient ruins destroyed truly your friends, or did Dagoth Ur have the right of it the whole time?  You may need mods to actually side with the seemingly crazed living god, but even without them, you can see that he may not actually be the villain all the citizens of Morrowind are making him out to be.  That ambiguity makes for a fascinating main story, and unlike the later games, it's paced very well for an open-world game, because your foe is a schemer.  He's incredibly dangerous, but you never know how imminent that danger is.  There's no false sense of urgency; instead, there's a sense of inevitability about impending doom if you don't act.  You can leave the main quest completely alone in favor of side quests for hundeds of hours right in the middle and go back to it afterwards and it still feels like it makes sense in-game.The guild quests have no overarching story, but their self-contained stories are generally interesting, and it's far less immersion-breaking to become the head of every major faction because A) you need the skills that faction cares about to ever be promoted anywhere near that high, and B) as the Nerevarine, you are a uniter of squabbling factions against the threat from Red Mountain, and so it makes some sense to have you leading numerous guilds that would otherwise oppose each other when you need to make arch enemies cooperate in the face of a common threat.The side quests are also quite good, all of them hand-placed and written with care.  None of those stupid strings of radiant dungeon-delving quests we got in Skyrim.  Also, remember all those little pieces of DLC made for Oblivion and sold for a few bucks each?  Remember Horse Armor?  Well, Morrowind has a few of those as well, but they're completely FREE.  Nothing as stupid as horse armor, either.  Instead, you get small but good dungeon mods, short but decent quest mods, item mods with and without quests attached, and small immersion increases, and none of them cost you a penny.  They are also all excellent, and generally recommended, except where you can find versions you prefer made by the community around ideas they got from the official version.Finally, I would be most remiss not to mention the magic system.  There are all sorts of crazy things you can do.  Enchanting is also much more versatile than in Oblivion, let alone Skyrim.  On-use magic items are something that Oblivion did away with completely, but in Morrowind, you could use a ring to summon creatures, or an amulet to shoot fireballs.  Enchanting weapons with constant effects is gone in the later games as well.  Beyond that, people of a particularly diabolical mindset have been known to enchant robes with constant effect damage health and place them on NPCs they want to see die, and on-use items allow you to get powerful effects that would be beyond overpowered if they were constant, either at the level you get them or at all.  Furthermore, no TES game since has had anywhere near the diversity of magic effects found in Morrowind.  Spells having a chance of failure if you try to cast ones that are too powerful is also something that makes sense to me as a lover of fantasy and an effective self-balancing mechanism.  Yeah, you could try to cast that enormous fireball, and if it hit, everything you're after would die...but it only has a 55% chance of succeeding, and would drain most of your magicka to boot.  Maybe try something safer?  This means there's no hard skill checks, no magic number at which you suddenly get access to spells you couldn't cast before.  If you have enough magicka and are willing to take the chance of failure given, you can try any spell you can think of.  You might have to increase your skill for it to be worth the risk in the heat of battle, but trying new things in the middle of combat has always been a dangerous move in any case.  But it could pay off...

content:
19, 2015
												One of the greatest games I have ever played.    I just want to highlight the skill system here, for some of the good and inherently bad things about it.The thing about the skill system in Morrowind is that it has many skills and possibilities, but it is solely based on the gods of RNG. The thing that's so bad about this (or, based on your perspective- good), is that everything you do is based on a percentage, a number, a sliver of chance as a new character. This means that even if you are an extremely powerful level 50 character, mastering all there is to know in the school of swordplay, you'll still have a chance of completely missing the enemy and doing no damage.   Another thing I see people fail to realise in their nostalgia is the fatigue system. There is literally no reason for me not to be able to throw fireballs at people's faces because my Fatigue is low. And because of this, the chance of casting is significantly lowered...that's all I'll say about that. It's incredibly aggravating.   The Graphics...they're extremely dated and about 13 years old. They haven't exactly aged well. But although this game doesn't look terrible, it can still be jarring for a new player to come from Skyrim or Oblivion into this game.   The Gameplay isn't incredible, but still fun. Even despite it's odd skill system. It's Classic RPG fundamentals are, in a way, the lifeblood of this game, despite it's oddities. In no other game can you walk up to a slow-moving mudcrab at level 1, completely miss every swing, and get yourself killed. Despite this, you can do anything you want, kill anyone or anything you want, steal, plunder, or even become the Grandmaster of almost every guild. Despite this, the game does NOT hold your hand. You have to work for what you want. Don't have enough gold for that Dreugh Helmet? Go to that dwarven ruin over the hill, kill everything inside, and find the treasures within. This game really captures the scope and expanse you would expect of an entire continent, even in just the space of an island. You can be running through the rolling hills of the grazelands, and the next minute you're in the middle of Molag Amur, in the midst of pools of lava and ash. That being said, it still takes a while for that transition. Even for an old game, the map is huge.   The Story is one of the pinnacles of this game. In more recent years, the story has not been bland, per se- but rather, it has been turned into this constant story that the game will try to make you feel inclined to stay with until that story has ended. For example, in Skyrim the main story was very heavily forced upon you. They try to create this false sense of "urgency" that you just do not find in this game. You are thrust into this world with no money, no hope, and no future. You are not respected as an outlander. People don't like the idea of integrating the ignorant "n'wahs" into their society. As with anything in this game, you must earn their respect. There is tons of side-quests which, I will argue, are about 30-40% "Go fetch this for me" quests or, "Go kill this man for me". But even in these quests, Morrowind most definitely has an extensive story to tell, and quite an enthralling one at that.   The DLC in this game is phenominal! Much like the other Elderscrolls games, the downloadable content in this game is extremely good. (Minus the horse armor from Oblivion!) Rich, and deep with story- the activites and things to do in them are quite extensive. The first time I had gone to the Clockwork City in Tribunal, I KNEW that I would remember that experience in gaming forever. I was in awe of this world created by a man-turned-god. Which is a feeling you don't get in most games today.   All-in-all, I think that this is a great game- and definitely stands the test of time today. With a few mods (which are still being made in 2015), this game can definitely net you countless hours of mudcrab-bashing fun. Definitely worth picking up, if you haven't already.

И на почве уважения к пиратам, у которых качаю игры для пробы, перед покупкой. Но это прошлое.А по мне, Морр уже не устареет, живая классика с великолепной графикой. Ну чуть устаревшей. Он либо может затянуть с первой мелодии, либо с первой мелодии отвратить.А меня вот затянула рецензия на ещё вышедшую игру, вернее короткая новость в Навигаторе игрового мира вроде. Что смешно, тогда и заинтересовался игрой из за графики) Ну и комп кроме видеокарты, вполне Морровинд тянул.Потом было несколько прохождений, некоторый шок от того сколько всего пропустил в игре. r 2, 2014
												After playing almost 200 hours of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, I decided to give Morrowind a try, as everyone says it's the best entry in the series. I bought this game back in 2012, and played it for about 1 hour; I didn't like it at all, it started out slowly, I had to read a crapton of stuff, and I got easily lost in about half an hour, so I stopped playing it.Two years later, I decided to give this game another try. It's seriously one of the best RPG's ever.The game is slow, I simply accepted that and decided to take it all slowly, read all texts, even take notes IRL so I don't get lost and I remember important stuff; the graphics are a bit outdated, yeah, but nothing Morrowind Graphics Extender can't help; the lore is awesome, everyone seems important (except those slaves you free) to the game, the gameplay is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because it's dice-based, but it gets pretty cool in mid-end game, and the best part: The Soundtrack.Totally recommend this game, may not attract everyone, but those who like this type of game will fall in love with Morrowind.

content:
y 1, 2013
												Morrowind is pretty much where the Elder Scrolls series hit its turning point. It offers what made Daggerfall great, but streamlines it a great deal and thus makes it much more accessible to new players. Despite a clunky combat system, greatly aged graphics, and a buggy nature, it's an enjoyable game where the prospect of exploring the alien world presented on the island of Vvardenfell offers new and interesting locales and inter-faction conflicts to experience. Definitely well worth getting,

content:
er 1, 2015
												This was my first Elder Scrolls Game and is one of my favorite games of all time. I first played it on the Xbox. When I first saw my brother playing it I thought it was stupid as I seen my brother wandering the world and I always refused to try it. But one day he made me try the game and then I was addicted. When I first played the game I didn’t do any quest I just got a house the good old way by killing its owner in Ald-Ruhn, Gnisis and Khuul. Later on in 2008 I got the game for the PC and made mods that I dreamed of playing. I don’t mod the game anymore but I still play the game and it never gets old. I also play the game for quests now unlike I did when I first played and that the best part of the Elder Scrolls series. Your free to wander, kill, steal, help others, betray, travel by foot, swim, travel by boat or silt strider which is their stagecoaches, it was endless. And If you got bored I always started a new save and it was memories all over again. The two expansion packs Tribunal and Bloodmoon are the best expansions packs I've ever played in any Elder Scrolls game, especially Bloodmoon. It adds a green forest and snowy environment which isn't available in the rest of the game. And the Tribunal expansion only added a city but a big city to the game with a 20 hour main storyline which I thought was impressive and very enjoyable. And the free little add-on DLCs that were made by Bethesda are pretty cool too especially the Seige At Firemoth plug-in. I recommend this game to anyone who hasn’t played an Elder Scrolls game and if you have played an Elder Scrolls game you may want to get mods and high-res textures that make it more like the newer Elder Scrolls game so it doesn’t seem old to you such as the games combat, menus, or graphic. Its an older game and for some gamers its maybe too old for them and not enjoyable. If you unsure watch some gameplay to decide for yourself.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2016
												From my prespective, still the best game of The Elder Scroll series, might unfortunately remain so, and maybe the best RPG single person sand box exploration title ever published.I love the immersiveness and complexity of the gameworld, background lore and especially the underlying race / faction / personality reaction adjustments. The race selection is actually more than just a cosmetic choice especially in the beginning when your fame is low, with dominant Imperials having the easiest start and the enslaved beastie-races having the hardest get-go. I've actually gotten attached to the Imperials because that was first CHAR I ever created in Morrowind to give myself just that slight edge with the learning curve I expected to be pretty steep, which it was. I just kept on exploring and stubbornly figuring ways to get around my initial limitations, and am ever since faithfully enamoured. One such trick I particularly vividly recall was using Scroll of Icarian Flight - acrobatics +1000 if memory serves - when at some point I got a bit stuck not having yet figured out that "Levitate" is really a must! Or trying to frantically remember what I did with my sucky imperial armour, because I could not get my next assignment without knowing "where was my uniform."Also, the different regions feel distinct, as well as the most important factions actually have a network of outposts in the contient, requiring more than doing a few odd tasks to raise through the ranks.I personally strongly prefer the major/minor skills and attributes character build up: pimping up your character if you choose to is surely part of the TES legend!Graphically Morrowind vanilla version is obviously somewhat dated, but that has never personally bothered me.Would rate the main questline above both Oblivion and Skyrim perso. The soundtrack is "typical superb TES" as well, composed by good ol' Jeremy Soule.

content:
er 25, 2016
												Have replayed Morrowind at least three times..absolutely my favourite game. It is an older game and the graphics are not up to par with many modern games (plus you can still get "stuck" in a rock or fall through the floor, necessitating a reload) but the brilliant story line, rich and detailed world of Morrowind itself, huge open world (so much to see and do, you can get lost and die out there, so save often), and masses of quests are the reason I come back to play. Your character can be crafted in any way you want...stealth, melee, ability to mend your own gear, magic (so many spells). The game can still crash but I found the steam version much better than having the game on disc (less crashy)...saving often is a must. There  is also no real hand holding, so paying attention to your world, increasing your skills and reading (the conversations, books, your journal) will point you in the right direction (maybe...I did die a few times before I got the hang of the game). Absolute must play for rpg fans.

content:
er 7, 2015
												At first I was unsure if I would enjoy this game or not because of the people saying the combat system was tough or the quests were hard because there was no compass with a way-point telling you where to go since I was used to that stuff, but when I bought it I really enjoyed it. The lack of way-points gives you a reason to read every bit of text to find out where you're going to be headed and makes this game very engaging. The combat system led me to stop playing the game for about a week until I looked it up and found out that you had to be skilled in the weapon you were using and that enemies could dodge. Also I learned that you should sell items to earn money when you're starting off. Those made me be able to enjoy the game. So far at the time of this review I have 5 hours and I haven't gotten anywhere in the quests so I can expect this game to be a very long game. This game has aged very well for being 13 years old. I would rate this game 10/10.

												I've owned this since it released on XBOX.  This is truely a masterpiece which I have logged more than about 1000 hours in outside of steam with no problem.If you're one of the kiddies who think graphics are what define a game, go play Skyrim.  But if you're the one who loves and enjoys this classic of which is best in the series, this is for you.  This game is the most expansive in the series and contains a lot more to discover than in the next two games.  It is titled 'Game of the Year' but in my case I would scratch 'year' out of the logo and replace it with 'century'.This is one of the best RPG piece made ever in history, hands down.If it is your first time playing, you have to be patient as you progress because usually the beginning of the game is very slooooow, but it is worth it as you go.  There is lots of loot to collect and horde and many fun exploits (huehue) that spice the game up a bit.  There are lots of skills you will master in this game, just note that marksmanship is a bit finickey but you will eventually master it.

content:
er 27, 2013
												Perhaps the best RPG ever made. Graphics are a bit out dated, but there are mods for that. I recommend Morrowind Overhaul 3.0. It will set up most things automatically, and then let you set specific things that you want. It breathes life back into one of my favorite games.Don't be fooled by newer Elder Scrolls games such as Oblivion and Skyrim. This game is difficult to start up. It's unforgiving. You may die in the first cave. Don't give up though. Explore, gather loot, and learn how to best use your fatigue.There is no hand holding in this game. No quest markers, no fast travel (unless you use the town to town system and even that costs gold), and enemies don't level with you. You can wander into zones where you have no business being.I can not recommend this game enough. It's a masterpiece.

content:
27, 2015
												Good:You are truly free to go wherever you want and do whatever you want. The game world is incredibly rich and complex. The main story is amazing, but there are also a huge number of side quests, which the game actively encourages you to explore. I didn't even get past the first mission of the main quest in my first year or so of playing. Unlike the other TES games, you usually have to work hard to get the best gear, which makes it far more rewarding. Bad:The graphics aren't the best, although that can be fixed with mods. The combat system takes a bit of getting used to, although it can be very rewarding when you reach higher levels. Overall, this is probably my favourite game of all time. The graphics and combat are quite dated, but if you can get past that, you are in for a fantastic open-world experience.

content:
ber 4, 2014
												I bought this game back in the early retail days, but due to a fire I lost that copy. I recently found Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim on sale with all downloadable content/expansions for cheap here on Steam, so I bought them. I loved the sheer variety of the paths you could travel and guilds/factions you could join. You could enchant your clothing/armor and weapons with magical effects, pick locks, cast awesome destructive abilities, heal, affect your enviroment, etc. I liked the fact you had 10 major/minor skills that leveled you up, but I hated the level 50ish limit on your levels. In order to maximize your stat bonuses you needed to micromanage your skill growth to an absurd level in order to achieve the 100 stats.  Also, after you do the available faction quests (again, you can't join but ONE of the three Great Houses, which does make some sense, but you can join opposing factions, such as the thieves guild, and the imperial legion, or the morag tong, which is almost the same boat.) and the Great House of your choice and the expansions, you can roam the lands to find random quests from people along the roadways. Overall grade: 9.8/10

It was so fun because it was actually brutal on you unlike Skyrim and Oblivion that could make you god sometimes. You want something? Go out and kill ten mudcrabs and collect fifteen mushrooms then you might get 50 gold. Those mudcrabs lower your health? Okay say goodbye to those gold coins so you can get yourself healed. By far the best Elder Scrolls game in my opinion. If you don't have it, get it. If you do have it, play it. If you are playing it right now, you know what you are doing.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
31
												Ahhh, The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind! I want to start by saying that yes I am a fan boy, but I wont let that get in the way of giving the best, most accurate review of this game as I can. Years ago, this game as many remember, was released on the orginal xbox ( was also on PC but I mean come on) which is where the elder scrolls series reallllly took off imo, and back then I could not get enough of this game. So to keep it simple, ill make a semi-detailed list of the pros and cons of Morrowind:Pros:-The best story of all the elderscrolls ( an opinion but if you give it a chance, youll see why ) so far, very in depth and extremely detailed.- THE MUSIC, MY GOD THE MUSIC. They actually used a sample of Morrowinds theme song in Skyrim, anyone who played morrowind before hand will have recognized it, thats how good the music is, tBethesda pretty much recycled it lol. You can get lost in the pleasent music and ambient backround sounds, and the combat music gets you on your oes in a split second. Playing Morrowind really makes me feel like im in a foreign land, an alien world. No other elder scroll game can capture that essence like Morrowind DID. This  set the bar reaaaaallly high, and honeslty I have yet to play another game where I was so enveloped in its atmosphere, it's captivating, magical and wonderful. - Character Customization/Class creation:  Same Races as the other Elder scroll games, not too in depth as far as how many types of face/hair etc you can choose. however the game has an awesome way of helping players to choose what role may fit them best which is unique ONLY TO MORROWIND. You can customize your class completely from the ground up, choose from a list of pre-set classes, or answer a series of questions and depending on how you answer these questions, the game will suggest a class for you. ( which you do not have to take if you dont want )- The NPC's : Morrowinds NPCs are very interactive, there are 3 different forms of persuasion you can use to try and get information from NPCs, not only that but there are many other ways to get information needed. Simply being a good person in game will help you, unless you decide to go on an extreme killing spree without going to jail, people will be afraid of you, word of who you are will travel across the land, and in some events NPCs will completely refuse to speak to you yet alone help you. - Vvardenfell is the continent Morrowind is held on ( if you get the GOTY, which I would highly suggest if you enjoyed the regular version, can port your character right over ) and during your travels ( you will have access to something that can transport you from town to town for a small cost, its called a SIlt Strider, looks like a giant flea and can be found in most cities) you will find tons of ruins, mines, bandit camps, and much more to explore. Vvardenfell has so many secrets hidden and locked away, and among those secrets is the tresure, the loot, the good stuff. There are tons of quests, and guilds, and side missions to do;  unlike the newer ES games, Morrowind is set in a harsh land where things are much more powerful than you are, and forces you to flee until you get stronger or can formulate a soild plan of attack and escape. There is no random loot, things are where they are which I personally like, it always gave me a particular goal to work towards like killing that guy for his armor, or robbing a certain store and teleporting out before the guards come. - THE MAGIC SYSTEM! Again, unlike any of the other Elderscroll games, Morrowind allows you create and customize your own spells.  ( one CON is that while casting spells, you have a chance to fail completely and use up mana which will make the start of the game very tough) Now there is a limitation to this; you must have the required skill level of magic in order to successfully cast a spell. You can make any spell you'd like, but in reality some you just wouldnt be able to cast if you make them too crazy. Was def one of my favorite things about the game, being able to make my own spells. There are spells in Morrowind that were removed ( jumping spells, levitating spells, MARK AND RECALL...) in Oblivion and never made a return, sadly. Now, the CONS:- RPG like combat. This means early on, when you start your game it will be very tough to kill things. You will swing your weapon and miss over and over until a few blows actually land. The thing with Morrowind is that even RUNNING drops your fatigue, and with lower fatigue your chance to cast spells/ strike your target decreases . So, the less stamina you have, the lower the chance youll have to hit something/ cast a spell. This can make the game frustraiting for some players, pushing them away from the start. As your skills go up , naturally so will how much you are able to hit something or cast a spell, once you get a skill to 100, you will always hit no matter what, but fatigue will still effect how much damage you do per swing etc. If you're really liking the game, just push through this- find the correct trainers for your skill set ( mages guild, fighters guild, theives guild, Morag tong [ assassin guild ]  etc ) and this wont be a problem for very long.  - Vvardenfell- IS IT TOO BIG..? It might be, for those who dont have an adventerous spirit, you might find the world too expansive.  Often times you will have to run on foot ( or use spells...!?!? ) to new destinations, and it is possible you can actually get very lost .  There are a lot of other ways to travel around Vvardenfell, and youll figure that out in time, but still looking for a partclar person or a particular place in such a large world can be extremely difficult and at times, demoralizing. - EVERYONE AND ANYONE CAN BE KILLEDIt would do you well to remember this, because in the newer elder scroll games they disable the ability to kill characters who are important to the main story. Well, in morrowind you may kill whoever youd like, whenever if youre powerful enough. You will not knock them out, they will be killed. The NPC will die and you will be able to loot them. HOWEVER..if and when you kill a NPC that is important to the main story, a large box will appear in your bottom left hand corner warning you of what you've just done, and how in doing so the main story line has been severed and you can never finish it. At which point you may reload your game, or you can carry on and keep playing because the rest of the world is still in action with plenty to do, but I wouldnt suggest it. -THIS GAME IS TOUGH. Morrowind can be very unforgiving. Save often or else youll find yourself losing hours of progress, which is extremely disheartening. -ALL IN ALL- The Elderscrolls 3 : Morrowind is wonderful game that has a tough learning curve, its not nearly as easy to play as  ES4: Oblivion or ES5: Skyrim and so if you dont want a challenge, a real one, don't pick it up. However if youre a big fan of the Elderscroll series, and you like games where you can see real progress overtime,  pick this gem up, you wont regret it. This is one of those things in life where you wish you could forget about it ever existing, just so you could go back and discover it all over again for the first time.

content:
y 10
												There's just something about this game that really hit the sweet spot for Bethesda RPGs.  It's not cut down significantly like recent Fallout/Elder Scrolls games, but at the same time it's not so huge as to be an impossibly glitchy mess like Daggerfall.  This is probably my favorite Elder Scrolls game despite the hiccups.Keep in mind that this being an Elder Scrolls game, many of the cons can be patched away with mods.Pros:- Much greater amounts of unique text than modern Elder Scrolls games.- Spell-crafting system is pretty much unlimited and is really fun to mess around with.- Environment and wildlife is very strange; it's unusual to have a game with the entire ecosystem based on a harsh volcanic island, never mind the magic influence.- Plot is very interesting and can be as deep or shallow as you want to put the effort in to be.- You can choose to kill quest-vital NPCs, and the game will kindly tell you you've done so in case you wish to re-load. (Much nicer option than "NPC just won't die for some reason" in later games)Cons:- 2000s-era graphics and a lot of unvoiced lines, if these things matter to you.- Random townsfolk tend to not have anything interesting to say if they don't have a quest for you.- Dice-based combat is not for everyone, and makes combat really difficult before you get more Agility/Stamina/Magic Skill.- The name of the game is Morrowind, but only part of Morrowind is present. (Of course, the game would've probably taken 5 extra years if it was all there...)

content:
, 2014
												I have well over 500 hours in Skyrim (counting all platforms), 350 hours in Oblivion and probably around 350 hours in Morrowind in total...so far, and it is my opinion that Morrowind gives the best RPG and TES experience of this threesome (I am leaving out Arena and Daggerfall as I haven't really gotten around to playing them properly yet). The main story of Morrowind (which is the only real questline in the game without the expansions) is simply many levels above what is presented to us in Oblivion and Skyrim as I see it. Even though the graphics are now very outdated, I still feel the game world in Morrowind feels more "real" than in the two latest games - the reason for this is probably that Morrowind is much more lore-rich and that no matter where you go and what you do you still feel connected with the main plot and the workings of Dunmer society (which you will be intimately familiar with in this game).Morrowind's greatest asset is probably the sense of wonder and strangeness the game world instills in the player and its very rewarding exploration. Some have called Morrowind "the last real TES game", and while I'm not going to make that claim it is clear that the dumbing down of the series and the extreme hand-holding of the player in say Skyrim has not exactly made the series take a direction that I'm very happy with. In Morrowind you often have to read to discover what to do and where to go at times and at other times you will have to think - there are no quest markers in this game to ruin this part of the game. Many people complain about the combat in Morrowind, and reasonably so if the game is to be compared to modern action titles - this was never the point however: this game is supposed to be an RPG with many mechanics taken from table-top RPG gaming. Seen in this light the combat system is altogether decent and in my opinion can be quite fun. In vanilla Morrowind for instance you can not manually block with your shield, something that probably sounds ridiculous to modern players - it makes perfect sense though seen from the perspective of old-school RPG-gaming where it is your character's stats and abilities that govern the outcome of an action and not the players own skills of reaction and button-timing and what not.All in all I strongly recommend this game and I urge all fans of TES to try it out no matter their feelings about the lack of an action-oriented combat system, because in my opinion this game is simply a better RPG experience than we get in Oblivion or Skyrim. A far better one. Oblivion and Skyrim are games I will probably never play again (been there done that...), but Morrowind I will return to again and again.

												The Elder Srolls Series i think is one of those Love and/or Hate series because of its take on the RPG genre.The Story Lines are really deep and there is huge amounts of background lore scattered about through side quests, books in game, or even just by listening to the NPC's converse with one another. Insane, I know. Still one of the Largest free roam RPG's of its time probably even bigger than some AAA MMORPG's (before major expansions of course).Combat is where it was hit or miss with people, you can still attack at will, yet some features like your shield skills were based upon a hidden RTD (roll the dice) feature that rolled your chance to block attacks until it leveled up and made your shield skills grow. There is plenty of secret areas (not really secret anymore since im sure theyve all been documented and plundered since) and large areas and dungeons to explore.***If you want the Hardest play through possible without any help from the game or the gods, kill Vivec when you first meet him, loot the note and item from him. You will get a message pretty much the same one you get from killing any important NPC suggesting that you restart from a save. This is an Easter Egg***For those with a great computer i suggest grabbing the Morrowind Overhaul 3.0 (Final Version) mod which has many great graphical upgrades as well as bug fixes & tweaking options for better gameplay.http://www.ornitocopter.net/morrowind-overhaul/

												I played the heck out of Skyrim recently, and this one is so far my favorite in the series.-I personally loved the lack of fast travel, since it extends the gameplay and forces you to pay for traveling services, or go on foot and face the horror that is the disease spreading fauna of Vvardenfell.-I also loved the lack of quest markers. As a Nord Barbarian, I have trouble casting spells; but that makes sense since…Well… I’m not a spell caster. If I wanted to be a spell casting Barbarian, I would have to pay a trainer enough for me to not fail my spell casting as much as I currently do, while in Skyrim, as someone with a thief build, I would have to buy the Flames spell from a shopkeeper and burn some random mudcrabs in order to become a master of destruction.

content:
y 18
												What I love about this game is the way you can make each playthrough unique. What makes this game different from for example Skyrim, is how you have to specialise in skills in order to succeed. In Skyrim you can get good at everything, which isn't exactly something that could realistically happen. What this does also is that unless you in Skyrim keep making new characters before you reach a high level (which is what I did) there's not really as much replayability in that game. More things I love about Morrowind is the lack of skaling (which made Skyrim too easy at high levels and Oblivion too hard) and the quests. The combat is a bit dated though, so it takes some getting used to. The dialogue is also very stupid. Every NPC basically acts like an information dispenser. Also, there's not much voice acting, which is both a pro and a con. You can have more dialogue, you don't have to listen to the same voice actors on different NPCs like later TES games, but because of no voice acting they don't have much personality, a problem which is exaggerated by the fact that 95% of all NPCs have THE SAME ♥♥♥♥ING LINES. Don't be fooled by all those Morrowind fanboys who think every Elder Scrolls game since this one is awful in comparison, and that you're a filthy casual if you disagree with them. All 3 are awesome games IMHO, and I have both good and bad things to say about them.

er 26, 2016
												The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a classic Open World RPG. It allows you freedom to do what you wish, go where you choose, right after you complete the intro. It won't hold your hand, or coddle you though, so you have to play smartly... wander too far in the wrong direction and you may find yourself getting chomped or blown to bits by something way too powerful for you. The combat is kinda clunky, and in my opinion, one of the game's few weak points... but the depth you'll find in this game is something many games these days sorely lack. You could spend over 100 hours in this game and find half of what lies within it's world.  The characters, plot, and background lore are all carefully crafted, within a vast, rich wold.Play this game if you want a challenge, deep story, and love open world fantasy RPG's. Also, check out the mods and fan restoration projects that update this game's graphics to some surprisingly impressive levels for how old it is.

												This game is pretty old with old gameplay features but Morrowind is my favourite elder scrolls game thanks to it's wonderfull map and it's amazing main story. The world of morrowind is very mysterious and harsh, full of weird plants and creatures. Some caves are actually scary thanks to crazy sound effects and dark enviroments. There are strong, weird and sometimes funny special weapons and armor that you can find or earn by quests. You can only be in one guild at a time and this makes it feel more impactfull. You can still do enchantment and blacksmithing. There is also another feature wich I enjoy thats called spellcrafting. You can creat your own spells and make them crazy overpowered. You get levetating spells and jumping spells to get to places you can only get to if you can jump or levetate high enough. The weather is very cool, there are sandstorms, thunderstorms, clearweather and a day and night cycle. You are not allowed to rest in the cities and towns, you can only wait or you can go and sleep on your bed if you own one. If i'm correct you can also own houses in Morrowind. You still get to choos all races and you get to create your own class or choos from the premade classes. There are spears, staffs, longswords, shortswords, axes, hammers, bows, daggers and much more weapons.I feel the most involved in this world out of cyrodiil and skyrim.
