content:
6, 2015
												Morrowind is arguably the best in the Elder Scrolls series for several reasons which I will go into detail in this review. If you're on the fence about this game, hopefully I can bring some insight to the wary. Please note that Morrowind is by no means a perfect game, but has some incredibly redeeming qualities about it that will keep you coming back for more no matter your experience with other RPGs or Elder Scrolls games.You're sent to Morrowind on a prison ship along with one other, for reasons left unkown to the player, with a missive from the emperor himself. There has been rumours abound for a long time in Morrowind that Saint Nerevar, a powerful Dark Elf from ancient days past, would be reincarnated and rid Morrowind of the outlanders and protect her from it's enemies. The emperor has suspicions that the player may be one who could fulfill this prophecy, and sends you to the island of Vvardenfell within the province of Morrowind. There had been plenty of 'false incarnates' of Nerevar in the past, who claimed to be the reincarnated hero, but all of whom were proven false by the roaming Ashlander tribes that inhabit Vvardenfell. This is basically your introduction to the game.After you exit the prison ship, you choose your race and which skills to favour, and they basically hand you a note to deliver and tell you 'good luck!' From here, the world is open to you, and you can choose any path you wish. The world is truly massive and you can pursue whatever suits your fancy. There are few limitations in Morrowind as to what you can do; you can kill every single character in the game, for example, which the later Elder Scrolls games lack. You can rob entire stores, kill the 'false gods' (tribunal), claim an entire city as your own... The possibilities are rather overwhelming at first.The magic system is probably the best of any of the games, allowing you to create your own spells in several schools of magic, including the ability to levitate high above the ground or jump several kilometres in a single bound. You can use bound weapons and armor at the same time, and even create one spell to not only bind a weapon but also a set of armor to wear. The enchanting system is impeccable, allowing for 'constant effect' enchanting, which can allow you to heal your health constantly without the use of spells, or constantly have several flame atronachs or golden saints following you at all times. The spellcrafting and enchating in Morrowind offers a lot of different combinations and possibilities to make your character the most powerful being in all Tamriel.The combat system is clunky, and rather lackluster. Depending on your skill with a weapon, you will either hit or miss, even if you're aiming directly at the target. It is also dependent on how much stamina you currently have; if your stamina is low your chance to hit is significantly lessened (This however can be corrected with a constant effect stamina regeneration enchant). This is one of the more frustrating aspects of Morrowind, but after a certain point when you become skilled with a weapon it really doesn't affect the gameplay too negatively. It'll be hard in the beginning, but you will notice when your character truly begins to become strong.The story line is very in depth, and involves your quest to find out whether or not you truly are the reincarnated Nervar, or the 'Nerevarine,' as was prophecised by the Ashlander tribes. Along the way you will meet many memorable characters and enemies, delve deep into very dangerous dungeons and caves, and form alliances and bonds with the Ashlander tribes that live throughout Vvardenfell. Through these experiences the player becomes stronger and more aware of the world around them, and also what is at stake; the destruction of all Tamriel itself.This game also boasts a huge selection of items, including 9 different types of weapons (with appropriate skills to use them), dozens of different armor types, hundreds of different potions, hundreds of books, and more! Many of these items also have unique designs which makes for varied NPC enemies and exceptional loot; all of which has been hand placed in the world by the developers. No more random loot for you, you know where something will be after you've found it for the first time.There are also two expansions, the Tribunal expansion, which involves two of the three of the 'false gods' known as the Tribunal, and also Bloodmoon, which involves the exploration and salvation of the small island of Solthsteim. Both of these expansions feature extended gameplay, new types of armor and weapons, new enemies and even bigger challenges than the vanilla originally offered.There is something to be said about the NPCs and their relation to the player as well. Though on the outside, they're rather robotic, when you engage them in conversation you have dozens of topics that you can ask almost every NPC in the game, and many a time they will be different or unique responses depending on their relation to the player or their race/status. For instance, on my last playthrough I donned some Ordinator armor, which are the guardians of Vivec city and the guardians of one of the Tribunal, Vivec himself. Since I am not of the Ordinator order, I am not permitted to wear such sacred armor, and the Ordinators will attack me on sight for disrespecting their hierarchy. It's little things like that that make the NPCs just a bit more a part of the world than bumbling ways of retrieving information.I could go on and on about the things that make Morrowind such a joy to play, but really it's something that needs to be experienced rather than read about. And that's the key thing here, it's an experience, not just a game you play through and forget. There are plenty of little quirky things in the game that make it memorable, such as an orc who believes he's a khajiit, no matter how many times you tell him he's not he will not believe you. Or a man falling from the sky to his death in front of you, for seemingly no reason until you read his journal which explains what went wrong. All in all, this is my favourite game of all time, and if you can look passed it's flaws and dated graphics, you may find yourself of a similar opinion.Oh also don't let my played time on Steam fool you, I've owned this game for over a decade on Xbox original, played through it several times with friends on their consoles, and also on older PCs, with what is most likely over one thousand hours of play time. You can definitely get your money's worth with Morrowind.

8, 2014
												Morrowind is a game with one of (if not the absolute best) the best worlds/settings to be seen in an RPG, and a unique, enigmatic atmosphere. Just about anything you can see in Morrowind can be visited at some point, and just about every quest is designed to have natural alternate approaches. It is a world that is not only beautiful, but also fully explorable, with a rich, deep lore and interesting NPCs. Many people criticise Morrowind's combat, and the sometimes vague quest directions, but there is one rule you need to follow to enjoy Morrowind: Respect its advice and systems. There is the infamous idea of missing all your attacks, and failing all your spellcasts, but this only happens at low fatigue, and with the quests, the optimal way to approach them is to play like you're in Morrowind.Morrowind is often criticised for being antiquated, but honestly I think just about anyone with an open mind and enough patience and time can appreciate it, even today.

												Perhaps the best RPG ever made. Graphics are a bit out dated, but there are mods for that. I recommend Morrowind Overhaul 3.0. It will set up most things automatically, and then let you set specific things that you want. It breathes life back into one of my favorite games.Don't be fooled by newer Elder Scrolls games such as Oblivion and Skyrim. This game is difficult to start up. It's unforgiving. You may die in the first cave. Don't give up though. Explore, gather loot, and learn how to best use your fatigue.There is no hand holding in this game. No quest markers, no fast travel (unless you use the town to town system and even that costs gold), and enemies don't level with you. You can wander into zones where you have no business being.I can not recommend this game enough. It's a masterpiece.

content:
er 25, 2014
												In Morrowind, my character:-has killed a living god-destroyed an Aedric artifact-is the head of House Hlaalu-is amused by the Telvanni tradition of violently murdering political opposition-has talks and meditates with Vivec-shoots Daedra in the face with a crossbow-has achieved CHIM10/10 will play againSeriously though, the atmosphere in Morrowind is amazingly well-crafted. I cannot yet speak for any of the earlier games (as I haven't played them), but Morrowind really is the best TES game I've played. I started with Skyrim and worked my way back. It isn't just nostalgia bias talking when people say Morrowind is amazing; it truly is a culmination of very hard work and insane attention to detail. It rewards you and doesn't insult your intelligence by putting the solutions to puzzles on the wall *cough* Skyrim *cough*. Everything you do, from joining the Temple to fulfilling the prophecy of the Nerevarine, has a noticeable impact on the world. People react to your actions; Bethesda nails this quite well. Whether you're going out to kill Mudcrabs that dragged off a Guar from some random lady's farm in the wilderness or playing politics to manipulate the ebony trade in your house's favor, every moment of Morrowind is rewarding. But that's also the beauty of it: It doesn't force you into anything. Nothing just screams out at you. You have to put the work in to enjoy the game. And once you do, the world and its story slowly unfolds before your eyes. There are so many moments in Morrowind that grabbed me and opened my eyes on a new range of perspectives that there's absolutely no way I could ever hope to count them. Don't let anyone lie to you; this game is incredibly frustrating and difficult at times, but the reward for working through it is one of the best gamplay experiences of all time. My only hope is that Bethesda will make a game as well-crafted, clever, and gripping as Morrowind again some day.

content:
31
												Ahhh, The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind! I want to start by saying that yes I am a fan boy, but I wont let that get in the way of giving the best, most accurate review of this game as I can. Years ago, this game as many remember, was released on the orginal xbox ( was also on PC but I mean come on) which is where the elder scrolls series reallllly took off imo, and back then I could not get enough of this game. So to keep it simple, ill make a semi-detailed list of the pros and cons of Morrowind:Pros:-The best story of all the elderscrolls ( an opinion but if you give it a chance, youll see why ) so far, very in depth and extremely detailed.- THE MUSIC, MY GOD THE MUSIC. They actually used a sample of Morrowinds theme song in Skyrim, anyone who played morrowind before hand will have recognized it, thats how good the music is, tBethesda pretty much recycled it lol. You can get lost in the pleasent music and ambient backround sounds, and the combat music gets you on your oes in a split second. Playing Morrowind really makes me feel like im in a foreign land, an alien world. No other elder scroll game can capture that essence like Morrowind DID. This  set the bar reaaaaallly high, and honeslty I have yet to play another game where I was so enveloped in its atmosphere, it's captivating, magical and wonderful. - Character Customization/Class creation:  Same Races as the other Elder scroll games, not too in depth as far as how many types of face/hair etc you can choose. however the game has an awesome way of helping players to choose what role may fit them best which is unique ONLY TO MORROWIND. You can customize your class completely from the ground up, choose from a list of pre-set classes, or answer a series of questions and depending on how you answer these questions, the game will suggest a class for you. ( which you do not have to take if you dont want )- The NPC's : Morrowinds NPCs are very interactive, there are 3 different forms of persuasion you can use to try and get information from NPCs, not only that but there are many other ways to get information needed. Simply being a good person in game will help you, unless you decide to go on an extreme killing spree without going to jail, people will be afraid of you, word of who you are will travel across the land, and in some events NPCs will completely refuse to speak to you yet alone help you. - Vvardenfell is the continent Morrowind is held on ( if you get the GOTY, which I would highly suggest if you enjoyed the regular version, can port your character right over ) and during your travels ( you will have access to something that can transport you from town to town for a small cost, its called a SIlt Strider, looks like a giant flea and can be found in most cities) you will find tons of ruins, mines, bandit camps, and much more to explore. Vvardenfell has so many secrets hidden and locked away, and among those secrets is the tresure, the loot, the good stuff. There are tons of quests, and guilds, and side missions to do;  unlike the newer ES games, Morrowind is set in a harsh land where things are much more powerful than you are, and forces you to flee until you get stronger or can formulate a soild plan of attack and escape. There is no random loot, things are where they are which I personally like, it always gave me a particular goal to work towards like killing that guy for his armor, or robbing a certain store and teleporting out before the guards come. - THE MAGIC SYSTEM! Again, unlike any of the other Elderscroll games, Morrowind allows you create and customize your own spells.  ( one CON is that while casting spells, you have a chance to fail completely and use up mana which will make the start of the game very tough) Now there is a limitation to this; you must have the required skill level of magic in order to successfully cast a spell. You can make any spell you'd like, but in reality some you just wouldnt be able to cast if you make them too crazy. Was def one of my favorite things about the game, being able to make my own spells. There are spells in Morrowind that were removed ( jumping spells, levitating spells, MARK AND RECALL...) in Oblivion and never made a return, sadly. Now, the CONS:- RPG like combat. This means early on, when you start your game it will be very tough to kill things. You will swing your weapon and miss over and over until a few blows actually land. The thing with Morrowind is that even RUNNING drops your fatigue, and with lower fatigue your chance to cast spells/ strike your target decreases . So, the less stamina you have, the lower the chance youll have to hit something/ cast a spell. This can make the game frustraiting for some players, pushing them away from the start. As your skills go up , naturally so will how much you are able to hit something or cast a spell, once you get a skill to 100, you will always hit no matter what, but fatigue will still effect how much damage you do per swing etc. If you're really liking the game, just push through this- find the correct trainers for your skill set ( mages guild, fighters guild, theives guild, Morag tong [ assassin guild ]  etc ) and this wont be a problem for very long.  - Vvardenfell- IS IT TOO BIG..? It might be, for those who dont have an adventerous spirit, you might find the world too expansive.  Often times you will have to run on foot ( or use spells...!?!? ) to new destinations, and it is possible you can actually get very lost .  There are a lot of other ways to travel around Vvardenfell, and youll figure that out in time, but still looking for a partclar person or a particular place in such a large world can be extremely difficult and at times, demoralizing. - EVERYONE AND ANYONE CAN BE KILLEDIt would do you well to remember this, because in the newer elder scroll games they disable the ability to kill characters who are important to the main story. Well, in morrowind you may kill whoever youd like, whenever if youre powerful enough. You will not knock them out, they will be killed. The NPC will die and you will be able to loot them. HOWEVER..if and when you kill a NPC that is important to the main story, a large box will appear in your bottom left hand corner warning you of what you've just done, and how in doing so the main story line has been severed and you can never finish it. At which point you may reload your game, or you can carry on and keep playing because the rest of the world is still in action with plenty to do, but I wouldnt suggest it. -THIS GAME IS TOUGH. Morrowind can be very unforgiving. Save often or else youll find yourself losing hours of progress, which is extremely disheartening. -ALL IN ALL- The Elderscrolls 3 : Morrowind is wonderful game that has a tough learning curve, its not nearly as easy to play as  ES4: Oblivion or ES5: Skyrim and so if you dont want a challenge, a real one, don't pick it up. However if youre a big fan of the Elderscroll series, and you like games where you can see real progress overtime,  pick this gem up, you wont regret it. This is one of those things in life where you wish you could forget about it ever existing, just so you could go back and discover it all over again for the first time.

												A very difficult but rewarding and seemingly endless game! One of the best if not THE BEST Elder Scrolls game I've ever played. content:
y 10
												There's just something about this game that really hit the sweet spot for Bethesda RPGs.  It's not cut down significantly like recent Fallout/Elder Scrolls games, but at the same time it's not so huge as to be an impossibly glitchy mess like Daggerfall.  This is probably my favorite Elder Scrolls game despite the hiccups.Keep in mind that this being an Elder Scrolls game, many of the cons can be patched away with mods.Pros:- Much greater amounts of unique text than modern Elder Scrolls games.- Spell-crafting system is pretty much unlimited and is really fun to mess around with.- Environment and wildlife is very strange; it's unusual to have a game with the entire ecosystem based on a harsh volcanic island, never mind the magic influence.- Plot is very interesting and can be as deep or shallow as you want to put the effort in to be.- You can choose to kill quest-vital NPCs, and the game will kindly tell you you've done so in case you wish to re-load. (Much nicer option than "NPC just won't die for some reason" in later games)Cons:- 2000s-era graphics and a lot of unvoiced lines, if these things matter to you.- Random townsfolk tend to not have anything interesting to say if they don't have a quest for you.- Dice-based combat is not for everyone, and makes combat really difficult before you get more Agility/Stamina/Magic Skill.- The name of the game is Morrowind, but only part of Morrowind is present. (Of course, the game would've probably taken 5 extra years if it was all there...)

content:
y 4
												I played this ten years ago and it was brilliant, my first proper RPG game. Oblivion seemed to blow the graphics out of the water, and Skyrim did that again.Going back to Morrowind after 10 years was very interesting. It has the haunting foreboding of the island still intact, but the main thing I was happy to see again was the statistic system and the way skills progress.The overall character set up and stats feels far more like an RPG than the later games. Something I think should have been carried through.The level of lore present in Morrowind is pretty large and back then they were not afraid to just use text for the bazillions of minor NPC's that exist. Its great being able to walk up to pretty much anyone and ask them for gossip or a little about themselves.Having 10+ choices for conversations with NPC's makes it feel as if you can have a conversation with anyone, even if just in passing.I would love the series to port this to future games, give me more NPC's I can talk to. If they are minor NPC's and its going to break the budget, dont be afraid to use text.Dont be afraid to play this game either, if you like old school RPG's this one has a great storyline and lots of playable hours.It does require a good four hours of so of playing to start feeling like you can take on the world. Dont expect to be able to handle more than one bandit at a time at lvl 1...cause you wont.

content:
12, 2014
												The Elder Srolls Series i think is one of those Love and/or Hate series because of its take on the RPG genre.The Story Lines are really deep and there is huge amounts of background lore scattered about through side quests, books in game, or even just by listening to the NPC's converse with one another. Insane, I know. Still one of the Largest free roam RPG's of its time probably even bigger than some AAA MMORPG's (before major expansions of course).Combat is where it was hit or miss with people, you can still attack at will, yet some features like your shield skills were based upon a hidden RTD (roll the dice) feature that rolled your chance to block attacks until it leveled up and made your shield skills grow. There is plenty of secret areas (not really secret anymore since im sure theyve all been documented and plundered since) and large areas and dungeons to explore.***If you want the Hardest play through possible without any help from the game or the gods, kill Vivec when you first meet him, loot the note and item from him. You will get a message pretty much the same one you get from killing any important NPC suggesting that you restart from a save. This is an Easter Egg***For those with a great computer i suggest grabbing the Morrowind Overhaul 3.0 (Final Version) mod which has many great graphical upgrades as well as bug fixes & tweaking options for better gameplay.http://www.ornitocopter.net/morrowind-overhaul/

content:
ber 4, 2014
												I bought this game back in the early retail days, but due to a fire I lost that copy. I recently found Morrowind, Oblivion and Skyrim on sale with all downloadable content/expansions for cheap here on Steam, so I bought them. I loved the sheer variety of the paths you could travel and guilds/factions you could join. You could enchant your clothing/armor and weapons with magical effects, pick locks, cast awesome destructive abilities, heal, affect your enviroment, etc. I liked the fact you had 10 major/minor skills that leveled you up, but I hated the level 50ish limit on your levels. In order to maximize your stat bonuses you needed to micromanage your skill growth to an absurd level in order to achieve the 100 stats.  Also, after you do the available faction quests (again, you can't join but ONE of the three Great Houses, which does make some sense, but you can join opposing factions, such as the thieves guild, and the imperial legion, or the morag tong, which is almost the same boat.) and the Great House of your choice and the expansions, you can roam the lands to find random quests from people along the roadways. Overall grade: 9.8/10

content:
er 26, 2016
												The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is a classic Open World RPG. It allows you freedom to do what you wish, go where you choose, right after you complete the intro. It won't hold your hand, or coddle you though, so you have to play smartly... wander too far in the wrong direction and you may find yourself getting chomped or blown to bits by something way too powerful for you. The combat is kinda clunky, and in my opinion, one of the game's few weak points... but the depth you'll find in this game is something many games these days sorely lack. You could spend over 100 hours in this game and find half of what lies within it's world.  The characters, plot, and background lore are all carefully crafted, within a vast, rich wold.Play this game if you want a challenge, deep story, and love open world fantasy RPG's. Also, check out the mods and fan restoration projects that update this game's graphics to some surprisingly impressive levels for how old it is.

												This game is pretty old with old gameplay features but Morrowind is my favourite elder scrolls game thanks to it's wonderfull map and it's amazing main story. The world of morrowind is very mysterious and harsh, full of weird plants and creatures. Some caves are actually scary thanks to crazy sound effects and dark enviroments. The weather is very cool, there are sandstorms, thunderstorms, clearweather and a day and night cycle. You are not allowed to rest in the cities and towns, you can only wait or you can go and sleep on your bed if you own one. If i'm correct you can also own houses in Morrowind. You still get to choos all races and you get to create your own class or choos from the premade classes. There are spears, staffs, longswords, shortswords, axes, hammers, bows, daggers and much more weapons.I feel the most involved in this world out of cyrodiil and skyrim.

content:
31
												Ahhh, The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind! I want to start by saying that yes I am a fan boy, but I wont let that get in the way of giving the best, most accurate review of this game as I can. Years ago, this game as many remember, was released on the orginal xbox ( was also on PC but I mean come on) which is where the elder scrolls series reallllly took off imo, and back then I could not get enough of this game. So to keep it simple, ill make a semi-detailed list of the pros and cons of Morrowind:Pros:-The best story of all the elderscrolls ( an opinion but if you give it a chance, youll see why ) so far, very in depth and extremely detailed.- THE MUSIC, MY GOD THE MUSIC. They actually used a sample of Morrowinds theme song in Skyrim, anyone who played morrowind before hand will have recognized it, thats how good the music is, tBethesda pretty much recycled it lol. You can get lost in the pleasent music and ambient backround sounds, and the combat music gets you on your oes in a split second. Playing Morrowind really makes me feel like im in a foreign land, an alien world. No other elder scroll game can capture that essence like Morrowind DID. This  set the bar reaaaaallly high, and honeslty I have yet to play another game where I was so enveloped in its atmosphere, it's captivating, magical and wonderful. - Character Customization/Class creation:  Same Races as the other Elder scroll games, not too in depth as far as how many types of face/hair etc you can choose. however the game has an awesome way of helping players to choose what role may fit them best which is unique ONLY TO MORROWIND. You can customize your class completely from the ground up, choose from a list of pre-set classes, or answer a series of questions and depending on how you answer these questions, the game will suggest a class for you. ( which you do not have to take if you dont want )- The NPC's : Morrowinds NPCs are very interactive, there are 3 different forms of persuasion you can use to try and get information from NPCs, not only that but there are many other ways to get information needed. Simply being a good person in game will help you, unless you decide to go on an extreme killing spree without going to jail, people will be afraid of you, word of who you are will travel across the land, and in some events NPCs will completely refuse to speak to you yet alone help you. - Vvardenfell is the continent Morrowind is held on ( if you get the GOTY, which I would highly suggest if you enjoyed the regular version, can port your character right over ) and during your travels ( you will have access to something that can transport you from town to town for a small cost, its called a SIlt Strider, looks like a giant flea and can be found in most cities) you will find tons of ruins, mines, bandit camps, and much more to explore. Vvardenfell has so many secrets hidden and locked away, and among those secrets is the tresure, the loot, the good stuff. There are tons of quests, and guilds, and side missions to do;  unlike the newer ES games, Morrowind is set in a harsh land where things are much more powerful than you are, and forces you to flee until you get stronger or can formulate a soild plan of attack and escape. There is no random loot, things are where they are which I personally like, it always gave me a particular goal to work towards like killing that guy for his armor, or robbing a certain store and teleporting out before the guards come. - THE MAGIC SYSTEM! Again, unlike any of the other Elderscroll games, Morrowind allows you create and customize your own spells.  ( one CON is that while casting spells, you have a chance to fail completely and use up mana which will make the start of the game very tough) Now there is a limitation to this; you must have the required skill level of magic in order to successfully cast a spell. You can make any spell you'd like, but in reality some you just wouldnt be able to cast if you make them too crazy. Was def one of my favorite things about the game, being able to make my own spells. There are spells in Morrowind that were removed ( jumping spells, levitating spells, MARK AND RECALL...) in Oblivion and never made a return, sadly. Now, the CONS:- RPG like combat. This means early on, when you start your game it will be very tough to kill things. You will swing your weapon and miss over and over until a few blows actually land. The thing with Morrowind is that even RUNNING drops your fatigue, and with lower fatigue your chance to cast spells/ strike your target decreases . So, the less stamina you have, the lower the chance youll have to hit something/ cast a spell. This can make the game frustraiting for some players, pushing them away from the start. As your skills go up , naturally so will how much you are able to hit something or cast a spell, once you get a skill to 100, you will always hit no matter what, but fatigue will still effect how much damage you do per swing etc. If you're really liking the game, just push through this- find the correct trainers for your skill set ( mages guild, fighters guild, theives guild, Morag tong [ assassin guild ]  etc ) and this wont be a problem for very long.  - Vvardenfell- IS IT TOO BIG..? It might be, for those who dont have an adventerous spirit, you might find the world too expansive.  Often times you will have to run on foot ( or use spells...!?!? ) to new destinations, and it is possible you can actually get very lost .  There are a lot of other ways to travel around Vvardenfell, and youll figure that out in time, but still looking for a partclar person or a particular place in such a large world can be extremely difficult and at times, demoralizing. - EVERYONE AND ANYONE CAN BE KILLEDIt would do you well to remember this, because in the newer elder scroll games they disable the ability to kill characters who are important to the main story. Well, in morrowind you may kill whoever youd like, whenever if youre powerful enough. You will not knock them out, they will be killed. The NPC will die and you will be able to loot them. HOWEVER..if and when you kill a NPC that is important to the main story, a large box will appear in your bottom left hand corner warning you of what you've just done, and how in doing so the main story line has been severed and you can never finish it. At which point you may reload your game, or you can carry on and keep playing because the rest of the world is still in action with plenty to do, but I wouldnt suggest it. -THIS GAME IS TOUGH. Morrowind can be very unforgiving. Save often or else youll find yourself losing hours of progress, which is extremely disheartening. -ALL IN ALL- The Elderscrolls 3 : Morrowind is wonderful game that has a tough learning curve, its not nearly as easy to play as  ES4: Oblivion or ES5: Skyrim and so if you dont want a challenge, a real one, don't pick it up. However if youre a big fan of the Elderscroll series, and you like games where you can see real progress overtime,  pick this gem up, you wont regret it. This is one of those things in life where you wish you could forget about it ever existing, just so you could go back and discover it all over again for the first time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 22, 2016
												The first Elder Scrolls game I played was Skyrim and I got Morrowind and Oblivion later on to learn more of the background story. I assume I'm not the only one so this recommendation will be geared towards other people who are playing the series backwards.Pros: + Large and dynamic world (for the time anyway)+ Quests aren't spoonfed to you and you're challenged to figure out on your own where to go and what to do+ Many different factions for you to join and your choices will affect how other factions judge you. It's not like Skyrim where you can join the Theives Guild and Dark Brotherhood and no one seems to care.+ What happens in this game is sometimes referenced to in later titles so you get a better understanding of the Elder Scrolls universe+ No fast travel means you have to prioritize where you want to go. The ability to use silt striders and teleport with the Mage's Guild is a fair compromise. Some might see this as a con, but I think it's better this way. It forces you to explore more and get to know all the places along the way instead of fast traveling and missing out on things. Cons:- Combat is super clunky. Meelee fights are basically like rock em sock em robots. Even your shield is completely passive. - If a skill level is too low, it will always "fail." Weapon swings will always miss, ingredients can be mixed and used up but the potions won't be created, spells will eat up your mana but still won't cast, etc.- Stamina, referred to in this game as "fatigue," can run out quickly and you're practically useless in a fight once you've run out. If your enemy is strong enough, they'll keep knocking you to the ground and can't do anything but revert to your last save or wait till they kill you.- Your character runs really really slow when you first start out (you can level your speed or get items to make you faster later on) and you can move a bit faster by jumping while running diagonally which is kind of stupid if you ask me.- NPC dialogues in many situations are lazily copy/pasted.Overall I'd say it's worth getting the game even if you're more accustomed to Skyrim. The game is from 2002 so most of the issues with it are kind of forgiveable. Just keep in mind that if something isn't one of your main skills, you can basically forget about using it until you find someone who can train you in it, and that you should always have fatigue potions ready when you might get into a fight. I'd also suggest getting the MGSO mod to make the game look nicer and fix some of the bugs.

content:
ry 11, 2016
												I love this game and have played it many times over the years. There is a rich and complex lore. There are lots of quirky characters and some downright silly side quests. There is a sense of epic scale, both in geography and story. The two expansion packs offered solid additional adventures for the protagonist. You can be just about anyone and do just about anything. Graphics are dated but easily spruced up with mods--and there is of course a robust modding community still out there. Dealing with even simple encounters in the early few levels can be frustratingly difficult (especially given the percent chance to hit based on skill level, so even point-blank perfectly aimed attacks often miss), and if you have adequately leveled your character then the very end-game content can really reduce the game to a pattern of repeated clicking to kill things, barring a few overpowered encounters (rather disappointing, as it really makes obvious that so much of the way the player interacts with the game is through violence); besides these points, though, I would describe the game as nearly flawless (if it wasn't infamously and maybe even fondly known for a bevy of bugs). I would highly recommend, whether you've played any Elder Scrolls games or not. Never too late to give this great title a try.

content:
9, 2015
Disclaimer; I've moved to a modded version which doesn't log playtime, so ignore that at the top of this reviewIf I had to describe Morrowind in a single sentence, it would read as such;"It plays like Dungeons & Dragons, but with 3D renders and a real-time map instead of chracter sheets and hastily-drawn dungeon layouts sprawled across the dining room table."If you're a D&D player, then Morrowind will come naturally to you. If you're more into the hack-and-slash arcade pace of something like Skyrim, then this might not be the best because there's slow, there's glaciers, there's continential drift, then there's the pace that morrowind plays at.It's true, there's nothing really quite as satisfying as when you spend three whole days preparing to face a monster that's been terrorizing a town, balancing all your gear, tweaking things for best performance, and then when the fight comes the beast falls like a house of cards in front of your perfectly executed assault strategy.But the key part of that for most people is the "Spend three whole days preparing" part. Believe me when I say if you decide to just run in and hack at the thing, you'll be served copious amounts of rekt. Morrowind is a game that heavily rewards long-term strategy and heavily punishes short-term kill everything in sight behaviors.It's very immersive and has a rich, well planned out lore with lots of little hidden things to learn, but you better be prepared to be spending long hours leafing through the in-game books and scrolls to learn it.Graphics: 2/10Artistry: 9/10Action: 3/10Immersion: 12/10Overall: 7/10

content:
, 2016
												Morrowind is an amazing game. No game quite captures the freedom or charm of Morrowind. If you can get past no fast travel, dated graphics, and awkward fighting system (Which can be fixed with mods if you really care that much). Morrowind is a sandbox of creativity, there is little to none hand holding. You can enchant or create essentially anything you want. You have to earn everything you got and once you have it its probably one of the most satisfaction i've had in a game, and damn is it fun getting there. The characters you meet, the bizzare experiences you are thrusted into, or seeing some hideous beast that one hit kills you. Everything you do in the game is a journey a quest all up to you it gives you an astonising amount of freedom in this little, detailed, harsh, bizzare, and beautiful world. You can spend hours roaming a city and not discover all that you can. You can create a ring that makes you fly 10,000 feet in the air. You can slay everyone you meet and conquer the world if you really wish. I highly recommend Morrowind and all its charm and harshness and freedom.

content:
30, 2014
												Golly gee wiz, just going through the first few reviews of this game wasn't a walk in the park. Granted, many have made valid points and I do agree in some aspects, but some may have been a tad bit biased. That being said, that's not what this is about. Now, let us move on to the actual review, shall we?Ahem.Let Blue the Bard (that me) tell all you lovelies a teeny tiny story. A story that you may or may not rage at, but that matter is entirely on your part, not necessarily mine. Blue will admit that they got into the Elder Scrolls series by first playing Skyrim. I know, I know, how n00bish and lame of me, but please, spare Blue the Bard a moment or two! Thing is, Blue hadn't even  heard  of the TES series until Skyrim came out. And even then, they didn't even play it at that time (when it first came out in 2011). Skip to a few years and one of their good ol' friends caused Blue to perk an interest in the game. They were curious, so they decided to try it out. And, to their surprise, they loved it! Blue wanted to get into more of this series, so they did. Blue tried their hand at TES I: Arena. A bit of a hassle, that one is: what with the DOSbox thingy and remembering the commands, etc. But Blue had minimal knowledge in that area so it wasn't so bad. Skip to a few weeks or months later and TES III: Morrowind and TES IV: Oblivion went on sale. Blue acted quickly and purchased them. First, they tried Morrowind, seeing how that game was released first out of the two. Okay, so I lied. THIS is where the actual review starts. Blue was very mindful as to not have been biased in any manner, for such a thing is a spell for disaster. They reassured themself that "hey, this is an old game. It's not gonna be fancy-pantsy pretty like them later installments. And maybe the mechanics and gameplay are slightly different. You'll just have to go through with it, like other people have."Well, I played it, and I loved it. Sure it is a tad bit more complicated, and there are indeed things I could complain about (initial player speed and limited voice acting to name a few specifics) but those aren't things worth giving up this game for. In this game, Blue is nearly unbiased, for they lack the nostalgia factor and they have an understanding of this game being an older thing.Honestly, despite the early graphics, Blue felt immersed. Here they were, exploring this strange and magnificent land. And, in Blue's humble opinion, this installment has the most relaxing music track. And that is a good thing. Blue felt..happy playing this game. Despite the fact that they have obviously played more Skyrim and Oblivion than Morrowind, Morrowind is something Blue can always come back to. There is still so much more to be explored, after all. And they look forward to it. c:And that's my review for The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind.

content:
y 10, 2015
												Game:The best game I ever played. Even though it says I haven't played that much on steam- I've played it on my Xbox Original, which had many disturbing glitches. On the Xbox, you could jump before entering a dungeon or house and get killed randomly. This game can be really hard to sit still when your walking around, and really annoying when starting out the combat system (MISS MISS MISS MISS) but when you skill up and become better, it's a lot more fun. I recommend being a Mage class, because later you can make spells! I do misuse the spells for jumping across Morrowind, and Fortifying spells to increase my Stats permanently but don't overdo it like me. I recommend this game, however check out the videos of the game before buying in case if the modern games have 'Spoiled' you. MODS:Sadly this game didn't include Construction Set, which ables you to modify the maps. I like to use it to make my own castle, home, and make it more interesting. There's no Mod-community workshop on Steam but do not fear because there is another place you can get mods called: Nexus.  Look it up. (Forbidden to link, Sorry!) Once you check it out, look at my profile: FastxNxDeadly - I have endorsed all my Mods that I installed, Including the Construction Set mod.You can transform a classic looking game into Skyrim if you want to. With mods, it can be really fun.Update: Since the the personal Award for 2016, I'd just like to update this personally. Since Daggerfall isn't on steam, Morrowind is still a piece of what everything turned out to be because of Daggerfall. So I want to thank this game so much for all the years of childhood gameplay.

content:
ry 7, 2015
												Back on xbox it took me a few years to beat the game even with cheats.Buying on PC was probably the most nostaglic thing I did. I started out like I normally did with my old plays and then I came across the console. My trolly side just couldn't help it'self. I created a new play, maxed out my character so all my stats were full. I took an amazing 1 minute journey to Red Mountain from Seyda Neen. Into the depth where the great and powerful Dagoth Ur resided. He greeted me, claiming of course that I had come unprepared. Insulted that he would even suggest that I was lacking the required materials to defeat him I had used my own godly powers to prove him wrong. With Sunder, Wraithguard and Keening suddenly in my posession the Dagoth Ur was curtain that he was ready to take me on. When he thought that I was going to attack him with the one of the weapons I had insulted him by drawing the iron dagger that you get into Census and Excise office at the very beginning of the game. With two swift hits he decided that it be best to move along into the next room. He of course does the normal dialtic claiming that he is a god, but that did not sway me. with a few more hits I had managed to knock the weak god into the pool of lava. I continued to foil his master plan which he was none to happy about. After promptly gloating and leaving the room I was greeted with the final cut scene of the game. That was it I had won. I decided to humour myself some more. I took it upon myself to pay a visit to Caius in Balmora. Turns out I could still take part in all the main story quests that lead up to the magnificent display of my powers. I was quite pleased by this.10/10 would use console commands again.

												Here is an honest review on the Elder Scrolls III Morrowind just a quick note that this is not nostalgia as I have played the elder scrolls games backwards.Music: Beautiful I honestly think that this is one of the best game soundtracks ever.Graphics: Not good but atleast its better then I or II.Enviroment: Small but with the constantly changing backgrounds it seems massive.Gameplay: some of the directions the NPCs give you are stupid and hard to follow (this game has no quest markers so if you're a fan of the elder scrolls IV or V that might come as a suprise) but some of the quests have a quirky sense of humour and are fun and rewarding the NPC's aren't static and are somewhat believable but many of the non main-quest related have copy-pasted lines which is kinda stupid but you can't blame the developers as at first the game was going to need as much memeory as next-gen consoles in three years time would struggle to cope with.overall I think thee elder scrolls III morrowind is a flawed masterpiece much like the original legend of zelda which made way many much better sequels.

												This is in my OPINION the best Elder Scrolls game made to date. There is so much to do in this game that it can be scary. There is even a unique item in a chest floating myriad meters above lava! That is a difficult item to get i tell ya. There are numerous factions in the game to join, more unique items then you can count on your hands and feet, a gargantuan number of dungoens to explore, as well as numerous fantastic mods available for this title. The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is and will be for a long time a game in my top 5 best games of all time list. If you are looking for a game to waste hours of your life on Morrowind is the game for you. Mind you it doesn't have the same feel as Skyrim or Oblivion and it is a game that is still selling copies on copies a decade after its release in 2002/2003, it is a fantastic title worth the buy.

												Morrowind is likely the best game I've ever played; there are no boundries to what you can do, and even after twelve years there's still a huge community for the game. And for those who need a visual boost, there's the Morrowind Overhaul which makes the visuals more up to date and is infinitely customisable. The only real caveat is the bugs, oh the bugs! But those can easlily be fixed with Morrowind Code Patch and Morrowind Patch Project, two very important mods. 9.5/10

												Welcome, N'Wah to the wonderful and unique world of Morrowind, they've taken you from the Imperial City to Vvardenfell and now you're epic quest begins. When you first step off the boat onto the island you'll find streaching before you a game unlike Oblivion or Skyrim. This game does not hold your hand, this is not a "follow the quest arrow" simulator. This is not a game that scales everything and anything to your character. Morrowind is a game that will let you fail. You can make NPCs hate you so much they are prevoked into attacking you. This game is crafted for fans of role-playing games, not casual minded gamers.Who should buy this game? Fans intreged by the idea of a game that doesn't hold your hands. Fans of older RPGs. Fans who love depth, lore and replayablility.Who shouldn't buy this game? People who do not like RPGs, who REQUIRE modern "babby" mechanics like quick travel and regenerating health. People who can't find their way around their house let alone Vvardenfell.

content:
10, 2015
												For those thinking about trying Morrowind because they only started the series with later titles, you may find that Morrowind generally does hold up, though I recommend installing Morrowind Overhaul. Combat is a bit awkward as it relies on dice rolls based on your skills to even land a hit, but there are combat mods out there if you don't like that.If you're okay with reading you will get the most out of it. It's not as heavy as Pillars of Eternity, but there are some parts where you'll need to read a couple paragraphs to understand what's going on. This was the age before the quest compass too, so you'll need to read about and look for clues as to where you're supposed to go. For example, 'look for the fangs of whats-his-face and walk South', and it's referring to a rock formation—or 'he lives at the East end of this road', and you actually have to look for that road and head East. Morrowind does, however, explore the lore and history of the world better than any of the other titles, and it's setting is the most mature and interesting—dealing with drug addiction, slavery, bigotry, religious extremism, and the sex trade in ways that other Elder Scrolls titles never fully got into.Click here for gameplay sample with Overhaul 3.0 installed.

content:
ry 15, 2014
												Definitely one of, if not the best, Elder Scrolls games. Morrowind's combination of amazing music, immersive story, and fantastic RPG elements definitely make it one of the best games I've ever played. Now since it's the year 2014, the graphics for Morrowind are considerably... laughable, but that's not reason to turn down this amazing game. If you're like me, and you play games mainly for the story, then give Morrowind a shot. It combines the use of directional sense and pen & paper when it comes to quests. You are not given a map, nor quest markers, so you are required to read the quest's objectives and find the goal yourself. I find that writing down locations and drawing a map are extremely useful when venturing out into the land of Morrowind, so you should give that a try too. The game heavily relies on character skills, attributes, and automatic dice rolls when it comes to just about everything. Combat is all about how likely you are to hit your enemies with your current abilities and attributes, rather than you making contact with your weapon. I've been in a number of frustrating situations where I flail my sword against my enemies, only to have me character miss with every swing. However, this is how things worked with table top games such as D&D, and it's nice to see it transitioned to video games, even if it was just the one of the few times. A combination of soothing music to lift the hearts of many adventurers, and intense gameplay, make Morrowind a definite must-play for all RPG fans.

content:
er 31, 2015
												Before I'd begin, I'd like to say the only Elder Scrolls game I have played prior to this is Skyrim, which I have played since release. I had always been interested in the other games if nothing more then for lore.Morrowind is an interesting game, from my perspective. Coming directly into this after Skyrim, it's a much different experience. I bought the Game of the Year edition to get the full experience, as I had been told this was probably the best Elder Scrolls game. I booted it up, and started playing.The first thing I noticed is... Morrowind is NOT too kind to new players. You're thrown into the world with little to no direction other then go here and deliver a package. Which is not entirely a bad thing. Morrowind gives a sort of feeling of freedom, and pushes you to discover how things work on your own. While in Skyrim, there WAS a sort of feeling of "freedom", but if you did not do the main quest immedietally, or at least go into it, quite a few things were sealed off, like shouts and dragons. And the main quest always sort of felt like it was looming in the background and that I was screwing up by not playing it. Morrowind however, presented more of a... "Take your time to get to know the place" feel. How I can describe it from what I've played thus far? It's a lot like Dungeons and Dragons. You're thrown in, you pick your race, what you're good with, and your special skill/sign. Then you go into a world, get told your main quest... And then you do whatever you feel is right at the time. What REALLY gives it the DnD type feel to me is probably the dialog, which is fairly unique in feel.I'll probably come back to redo this review once I get a few more hours in, or at least enough knowlege of how to play the game correctly. This is my first impression review from someone who never played Morrowind. Thank you for taking the time to read my review.

content:
ry 6, 2016
												Where could I possibly begin?The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind is perhaps the most notorious title within the Elder Scrolls franchise. While the age of Morrowind is more than evident in it's antiquated graphics it's sheer complexity and depth more than make up for any perceived shortcomings. Players seeking literally hundreds of hours of gameplay, exceptional modding capabilities and immense lands to explore will be more than satisfied by purchasing this game.Downfalls to new players would likely include limited fast travel options, at times overly complex skill selections during character creations and the graphics as mentioned before. Graphics and textures can all be improved with the use of 3rd party mods which have saturated the internet to this very day.Hardcore Elder Scroll and RPG fans will be sure to enjoy Morrowind.

content:
, 2016
												Recently I've come to the conclusion that Morrowind is my favorite Elder Scrolls game.  It was a true old-school RPG, of which only some elements survive in modern games.  There was no fast-travel, quest markers, or the ubiquitous crafting system that seems to be the same in every game nowadays.  There was only adventure! Morrowind is one of the biggest Elder Scrolls games by area and you can get lost for weeks in and out of game exploring all that countryside.  If you haven't played Morrowind, please do so! You'll be much better for the experience!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 28, 2013
												Most of you have played or heard about Skyrim and Oblivion. What you may not know is that neither of those games could match the mature tone and sense of mystery and wonder that Morrowind mastered. It certainly doesn't looks as good as those games, and the combat isn't as sharp, but it outshines them both in challenge and in freedom. Morrowind does not hold your hand; it does not direct you to points of interest and give you tips on how to improve. It simply offers a massive world to you and lets you do with it as you wish. Of course the main story wil show you a path, but don't expect waypoints or fast travel; You want to progress? It's all on you. And it's all the more rewarding because of it.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 6, 2015
												I've noticed that the reviews for Morrowind, Oblivion, and Skyrim tend to be about why that game is the best Elder Scrolls game and the others are terrible in comparison. I really enjoy all three of them (sorry, Arena and Daggerfall, you're just not very enjoyable by today's standards), so I figured I'll give reviews for each that focus on what's unique about each of them, and what kind of players that will appeal to. Morrowind has easily the most vocal proponents of any of the three. They are very passionate about it, and insist that the latter two were disappointments. There's a pretty simple reason for that. It's easily the most chaotic of the three. What I mean by that is that you have far and away the most freedom and choices with Morrowind, but also easily the biggest negatives of the three games. Players who love chaos in their games tend to be the most vocal about what they want, so that's why you see Morrowind fans being the most passionate.For the positives of Morrowind, the aforementioned freedom is the biggest one. It doesn't funnel you into rapidly progressing through the main questline right away, and in fact discourages it through tying a need for certain levels in different skills to the ability to even receive many of the main quests. You are also free to decide which factions appeal to you, based on which skills you emphasize. Unlike Oblivion and Skyrim, you can't decide to progress all the way through the questlines of every faction. Several of them are incompatible with each other, so deciding which factions suit your playstyle is up to you. Morrowind also has the largest selection of spell types, armor types, weapon types, and even skill types (you can cast spells to blind enemies, use spears as your main weapon, and have all sorts of options not available in Oblivion and Skyrim). Another big draw is a beautiful soundtrack that really puts you in the game emotionally. The enchanted items also tend to be much cooler and more abundant than in later games. The recall and mark spells also provide a nice way to teleport out of danger or when you are overburdened. The environment is pretty cool, with swamps, ash storms, green plains, volcanoes and lava, and all sorts of other different types of scenery and climate.For the negatives of Morrowind, you have to be prepared to be much more frustrated with this game than you will with Oblivion or Skyrim. Many areas don't scale to your level, and so sometimes your freedom can be deceptive, as you can't realistically go to many parts of the island for a large chunk of the game without dying almost immediately. There is no fast travel to locations you've already visited, so you waste a lot of time walking the same roads over and over, or constantly paying for transportation between cities. The combat, magicka, and stealth dynamics are also much worse than in later games. Your magicka doesn't replenish on its own, so you have to either sleep, take potions, or wait far away from civilization (you can't use the wait function within a large radius of every town or city). Sneaking is a lot more difficult in this game, but less nuanced. A large portion of it is entirely luck based, regardless of how high your sneak skill is. The barter system is also fairly frustrating, with items costing exorbitant sums while merchants only have a small pool of gold to buy things with from you, so it takes forever to build up the large sums needed for many items.And now, let's talk about the biggest negative of the game, which also happens to be the biggest negative in any of the games: the combat system is terrible. Instead of your weapon skill determining how much damage you do, it determines (although somewhat loosely) whether or not your attacks connect. And even then, they will frequently miss. So you'll stand right in front of an enemy, swinging your weapon over and over, and very few of them will connect. Your fatigue affects it as well. A similar thing goes for spells, where every spell has a rather large chance of failing to cast, while still draining your magicka. It's the single dumbest decision Bethesda made with any of the Elder Scrolls games.This game is definitely worth it, although if you first play it after playing Oblivion or Skyrim, you have to change your expectations, because it is a lot less polished or refined than those two. If you love chaos/anarchy in your games, this will be your favorite. If not, it's still a great game to play, it just takes a lot of getting used to.

content:
2, 2014
												This game is the breaking point when Bethesda escaped the pixels, and was born into 3d amazingness. Though the graphics take some getting used to, once you break the 10 hour point, everything becomes an adventure, and here's why.1. Unlike its previous games (aka Daggerfall, Arena), Morrowind has a clear storyline for you to follow and make branched desisions off of.2. Unlike Skyrim, you can kill whoever you want, without them bowing down and regening their health.3. Unlike Oblivion, you can gain blessings from any shrine, all you have to do is donate some coin. (has a time limit)4. The island of vvardenfell takes an hour or so to cross, but will take 30 hours due to the amount of caves, ancestral tombs, daedric ruins, dunmer fortresses, and much much more. 5. Unlike other games, you can choose from a plethora of guilds and groups to join.(a.k.a. House Hlaalu, House Redoran, House Telvanni, Blades, East Empire Company, Fighters Guild, Imperial Cult, Imperial Legion, Mages Guild, Thieves Guild, Ashlander Tribes, Morag Tong, and the tribunal temple. You can also join one of three vampire clans such as the Aundae Clan, the Berne Clan, and the Quarra Clan.)So with all included, this is a pretty amazing game that deserves the awards it got in its day, and still has talking points that Skyrim, Oblivion, Daggerfall, and Arena cannot compete with.

content:
4, 2014
												Absolutley fantastic game. My clocked hours is misleading, as i played most of this game during a car ride across the USA, btw. But to the point, this game is beautiful, in many ways. My favorite part is the environment and the atmosphere. Vvardenfel is such a strange place, you feel like your on another planet sometimes. Wandering through the ashlands, trudging through the swamps, or delving into a daedric ruin, there is tons of stuff to explore.  The dark elf culture is so vibrantly displayed, as is their reactions to other cultures. The customs and armors (especially bonemold, i love that stuff) are so peculiar and awesome, its like nothing you'll find elsewhere.  The sounds are great as well. The soundtrack fits perfectly with the game, however it is only 30min long, and the repitition gets a wee bit annoying sometimes.  The thing that i love the most about it is its complexity. This is not an easy game, and you need some knowledge to get through, unlike Skyrim, which was dumbed down for all the console CoD fans (still a great game tho). The leveling system works very well, the combat system does not. Using melee weapons is okay, but magic is freaking impossible. The graphics on this game are amazing, especially for 2002. They impress me even today. All in all, this is a great game. Highly reccomend it.

content:
ry 21
												Great game, annoying as all hell fanbase. I first came into the Elder Scrolls series with Oblivion and was absolutely absorbed into Skyrim once the game finally released. Now considering myself a die-hard fan of the Elder Scrolls, I took to the internet and found that many considered Oblivion and Skyrim to both be dumbed-down knockoffs of the series' true crowning achievement: Morrowind. I was intrigued by the idea that what had become my favorite game series was spawned from what was apparently a flawless masterpiece that I had yet to experience, so I picked the game up on Steam immediately. I was then treated to appalling graphics with a draw distance shorter than I can throw a football (which isn't far), characters who walked around like they'd just completed a cycling tour of Europe, and fetch quests galore (Gathering mushrooms for the Mages Guild, anyone?). I then forgot about the game for several months until the ESO update announcement put it back into my consciousness. I decided that I owed it to myself to figure out what it was that made people adore this game so much and started a new playthrough. This time, I felt that I was finally seeing the game's charm. Quests without objective markers meant that some modicum of mental effort was actually required to complete them, giving a real sense of weight and accomplishment to even the most simple of tasks. The story and lore were rich and layered, not shying away from unsavory topics like slavery, drug abuse, and religious persecution. The combat, while lacking the fun and dynamic feeling of subsequent entries in the series, gave a real sense of progression as levelling up enabled my character to actually hit enemies and successfully cast what spells that had once felt far out of my depth. I don't have too many hours into the game just yet, but I've explored a great deal of the map and progressed into the main story and can't wait to play for many hours more. I would recommend this game to any Elder Scrolls fan with the caveat that they'll have to look past the game's lackluster, outdated exterior to find the truly excellent experience within. Despite what its most rabid fans will tell you, this game is by no means perfect. However, it is a blast to sink your teeth into and definitely worth your time.

												Don't let my "hours played" fool you, I played this game before steam was a thing. My first RPG, and my favorite one to this day. The stealth system wasn't as workable as the newer ones, but you could say it was more realistic. Once enemies are on alert, they will find you, it's only a matter of time. Decided to go wandering the northern parts of vvardenfall before you even found your first enchanted weapon? Probly gonna have a bad time. Not only that, the fast travel is expensive early on, and you can't just fast-level blacksmithing and smith daedric armor like in skyrim. You want that daedric shield and sword? You're gonna have to kill that dremora over there for it, and he gets to use them against you first. And by the nine, use your journal, it will save your life.
